div.p: THE VOTARY OF WEALTH; A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
BY J. G. HOLMAN, AUTHOR OF "ABROAD AND AT HOME."
LONDON: PRINTED FOR T. N. LONGMAN AND O. REES, NO. 39, PATERNOSTER▪ ROW.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.byline: WRITTEN BY WILLIAM THOMAS FITZGERALD, ESQ.

lg.l: TO pleaſe the town is not a taſk ſevere,
Wit will command a ſmile, diſtreſs a tear!
And he, whoſe moral picture plainly ſhews
The tree of vice can bear no fruit but woes!
That, tho' ſucceſsful long in faſhion's reign,
The villain's wages are diſgrace and pain;
But that the good, by bounty wiſely given,
Can make this vale of tears reſemble heav'n!
With new-born comfort huſh the widow's ſigh,
And wipe the tear from pallid miſ'ry's eye!
The Bard, who thus employs his uſeful pen,
Imprints his drama on the hearts of men;
Commands reſpect from age, applauſe from youth,
And makes the ſtage aſſiſt the CAUSE OF TRUTH.
Yet, has an author many an anxious fear,
As his probationary night draws near:
When to his friends the manuſcript is read,
Each ſocial critic nods the approving head;
Moſt yield him flatt'ry—ſome with jaundic'd eye
Glance at a fault, and at a beauty ſigh.
But theſe are few—true genius ſtill delights
To gaze with rapture at the Muſe's ſlights!
And ſcorns to triumph at a brother's fall,
When Fame's wide dome is large enough for all!
Tho' none ſhall mount where Shakſpeare ſits ſublime▪
The drama's monarch to the end of time!
Within that fane they each a wreath may wear,
Which nature's darling offspring hallow'd there—
And ſeated at the baſe of Shakſpeare's throne,
Feel ſome ſmall portion of his fire their own!
Thus, if they knew their int'reſt, wits wou'd be
By friendſhip bound in one great family;
And, if deſerving, all might reap the bays
From the rich harveſt of the Public praiſe.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: SCENE I.—An Apartment in OLD VISORLY'S Houſe. OLD VISORLY and Lady JEMIMA at breakfaſt. OLD VISORLY reading Newspapers.

sp.speaker: LADY JEMIMA.
sp.p: A Very pleaſant, ſociable companion, indeed, Mr. Viſorly! can you pore over newſpapers at no other time? You compliment me moſt highly in letting me ſee that, while you are in my company, you need other entertainment.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: My dear, I beg your pardon. One is anxious, you know, for the good of one's country.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: You are anxious, Mr. Viſorly, for any thing that is to ſhew diſreſpect to me.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Lord how you talk—I ſhew diſreſpect to you! (ſtill reading.)

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: There! are you not ſtill inattentive to me and my remonſtrances? Ah! I might have known what I had to expect. This is the conſequence of loſing ſight of what was due to my birth and rank, and marrying a commoner.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: My dear Lady Jemima, why ſhou'd you urge that ſo often? I am ſenſible of the honor, and of my own unworthineſs.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p:
Still you pay no attention to what I
am complaining of. Any thing, I find, is preferable to my converſation.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Never ſpoke a truer word in her life (aſide.) My dear, I ſhall have done in a moment—I am among the deaths.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: I wiſh to the Lord you were.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Oh fie, fie, Lady Jemima!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: You would provoke the patience of a ſaint. [OLD VISORLY ſtarts up, he has been ſtill reading.] What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Tol lol de rol! (ſinging and capering.)

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: The man is mad.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Tol lol de rol!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: What frenzy has ſeized you?

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Frenzy, my dear! only the frenzy that ariſes from good news.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Can't you give utterance to your good news without ſuch abſurdity?

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Well, well, I will, my dear, (reads) "On Thurſday, the 14th of laſt March, died at an advanced age, at Calcutta in Bengal"—Tol lol de rol!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Oh, mad, mad!

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: "John Cleveland, Eſq.—his immenſe wealth devolves on his only ſon, who is ſhortly expected in England." There is a fortune for our dear ſon, Leonard!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: How do you mean for our Leonard?

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Mr. Cleveland, the ſon and heir of the deceaſed, is my firſt couſin—I'm his neareſt of kin—The old fellow, who is dead, was ſuch a capricious ſort of animal, that he might have left every ſhilling of it away from his own ſon; but now it is come into his poſſeſſion, it is in the fair road to our family.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: This, indeed, is welcome news;—and here comes our dear Leonard to partake it.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Ah, my dear boy!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Ah, my dear ſon!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Good morning—How do you do?

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Here is news!

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Ah, my boy, we have news for you!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, let me have it.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Why then—

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. Viſorly—I'll tell it him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I'll ſave you the trouble—Old Cleveland is dead at Calcutta—his ſon inherits all his fortune—And the good news is, that their bulſes and lacks may eventually come to our family.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Ay, my boy!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Yes, Leonard!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I would not give five guineas for the chance of inheritance.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No. I know a little more of the circumſtances than you do. Mr. Cleveland has a daughter.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Poh, poh! ſome—ſome—you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Mr. Viſorly, I am ſhocked at your indelicate alluſions.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I wiſh they were well grounded; but 'tis a melancholy fact, that the daughter is legitimate, and her mother, Cleveland's wife, is living.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Dear me, dear me!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: How do you know all this?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: From the moſt poſitive information.—Cleveland's own acknowledgement. He has written to me.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Really!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes—Stating that as we were the neareſt, and only male relations he had, to us he has taken the liberty of conſigning his remittances—with directions how he wiſhes them to be inveſted. Underſtanding that your reſidence in London was only caſual, and alſo thinking the trouble of buſineſs more ſuited to my time of life, he thought it better to addreſs his letter to me. In it, he explains all the particulars of his marriage; and recommends his wife and daughter to our attention.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: How—are they not with him?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No. His daughter we may hourly expect—Not being able to ſettle his affairs immediately on the death of his father, he ſent her before him, unwilling to detain her from her mother.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Why, is the mother in England?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes;—and has been for ſeveral years. His marriage was without the conſent of his father, and, for ſome time, unknown to him—Enraged when he diſcovered it, he inſiſted on a ſeparation,—to avoid ruin, which would have been the conſequence of his father's reſentment, he was forced to comply. The child was ſuffered to remain with him—The wife was doom'd to return to England, where, for theſe fifteen years ſhe has lived in retirement.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Well, what is to be done?

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: They are recommended, it ſeems, to our attention; but, really, I don't well ſee how I can reconcile to myſelf, taking notice of, and introducing to my acquaintances, people, one doesn't know who—and that have been living one doesn't know where,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
What do you talk of? Are they not the
wife and daughter of a nabob? Your high-bred friends will worſhip you for the introduction. Think what will be the magnificence of their houſe, the ſplendour of their equipage, the brilliancy of their entertainments. Such ſuppers as theirs will be the faſhionable world would ſcramble for a ſeat at, even if they were given by a perſonage from a hotter place than Bengal.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Leonard ſays very truly. We ſhall get credit by ſhewing ſuch gold pheaſants to our friends.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Certainly: for all will be charmed with the ſplendour of their plumage—even thoſe who are ſo little faſhionable as not to attempt plucking the feathers.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Well, we muſt prepare to ſhew them all poſſible civility.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Ay, ay, pray let us; for I have ſomething in view that will pay us for our trouble.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: What is that, ſon?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: The hope of making the young lady a part of our family.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: What an excellent thought! Ah, Leonard, Leonard, you are a cunning rogue!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: You amaze me, child, that you don't extend your views—My ſon, the grandſon of the earl of Caſtlegreat, ought to aſpire to the proudeſt heireſſes of the nobleſt peers—not ſtoop to a thing of muſhroom growth.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Conſider, mother, this muſhroom is the growth of a golden ſoil.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Well, ſon, purſue your own inclinations; my affection for you will always make me yield to your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Then this glorious fortune may be mine. Invite them to your houſe. The mother having
long experienced a conſtrained ſecluſion from ſociety, will, doubtleſs, be gratified with attentions from a woman of your rank—the daughter is young—I don't deſpair of ſucceſs with her; and the preference the father has ſhewn, in the truſt conſigned to me, makes me hope every thing from him. So, all ſeems fair for my ſucceſs; and half a million at leaſt is the prize. Think of that—think of that.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A perſon below deſires to ſpeak with you, Sir. (to Leonard.)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He ſays his own name is immaterial; but he deſired me to mention the name of Cleveland.

sp.speaker: Leonard.
sp.p: Shew him up directly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You are welcome, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir; thank you. So, I be got to you at laſt. You great folks take a plaguy time coming at. Ma'am, your humble ſervant. Mayhap, I ſhould ſay your Ladyſhip—Pray excuſe all faults.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Never mind, Lady Jemima doesn't ſtand on ceremony.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Don't ſhe? Why, then, Lady Jemima is a lady juſt after my own heart.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Well, Sir—you come concerning Mr. Cleveland.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p:
Why, yes, Sir; yes. You muſt know, Sir, that I am an old fellow that remember Mrs. Cleveland (Heaven bleſs her!) when ſhe was not the height of my knee. Often and often is the time that I have danced her o'top of it. Well, that is neither here nor there. When her father
died—Ah! I ſhall never forget it—he has not left a better man behind him—there was not a dry eye in the village except the undertaker's, and folks do ſay he cried a bit. Well, her father, good ſoul! had met with ſo many loſſes and croſſes, that there was little enough left for his daughter to live like a lady on; ſo ſhe was perſuaded by her friends to take a voyage to India with a couſin of her's, who had married, and was going to ſettle there.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Mr. Cleveland has acquainted me with the reſt. There he married her, and from thence, by the ſeverity of his father, he was forced to ſend her.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Ah, poor dear! home ſhe came again, miſerable enough, to be ſure. Well, mayhap, all for the beſt; now ſhe will be as happy as the day is long. But for this many a year ſhe has led but a loneſome ſort of a life; for you may think my dame and I, though we love her like a child of our own, can't have been company good enough for her: but ſhe was as kind to us, and made as much of us, as though we had been the beſt people in the land.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: We ſhall ſoon, I hope, have the pleaſure of receiving her in this houſe. She muſt not think of ſeeing any other habitation.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, certainly not. She muſt make this her abode.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Oh, to be ſure; to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.q: Why, do you know, now, this is the very thing that came into my head, and that I told her of—Says I, as ſure as I am a ſinner, if thoſe relations of Mr. Cleveland's have the leaſt bit of kind-heartedneſs about them, they'll never let you live in any houſe but their own.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: Certainly!—How right you were!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.q: And I am glad to find ſuch friendly good ſouls in this great town of London;—for, do you know, I had got a notion of its being but a bad ſort of a place.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: I truſt you will find it otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.q: Why. I hope I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: When did Mrs. Cleveland arrive?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: But laſt night.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: And where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Why, ſhe is at a—at a—What the plague do you call it? It is the like of an inn, only it goes by a finer name.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, an Hotel.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Ay, ay, an Hotel.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But what Hotel?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Od rabbit it, I forget the name of it; but I can aſk the man who ſhewed me the way here; for, as I never was in London before, I can't travel without a guide. He waits below to take me back again—he will tell me (going.)

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Stay, Sir, he ſhall direct us both. The carriage is waiting, and I will not loſe a moment in paying my reſpects to Mrs. Cleveland.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Well, now, that is kind of you, indeed, my lady. I will leave the direction below ſtairs, and go on before.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: By no means. Lady Jemima will take you in the carriage with her.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Why, you are joking ſure!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: (aſide to Leon) My dear Leonard, think if I ſhould meet any of my friends with this Bumpkin for my Ciciſbeo.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, mother, to oblige me (aſide.) My mother is ready to attend you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Pſha, Pſha! no tricks upon travellers. Her ladyſhip ride with ſuch a lout as me!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: It may well ſurprize you (aſide.)—Oh, Sir, I ſhall be proud of the honour.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: The honour! that is a good one. Come, then, my lady. Lord, how my dame would laugh to ſee me ſeated in a coach with a Lady Jemima!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Won't you accompany my mother, Sir? I have buſineſs which muſt detain me.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I will go with you, Lady Jemima (calling after her.)—I ſay, Leonard, where will her Ladyſhip wiſh the ruſtic if ſhe meets any of her noble relatives? Ha! ha! 'tis a good joke—Ah, Leonard, you are a droll dog! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Manet LEONARD.
sp.p: If my deſigns ſucceed, on what a pinnacle of fortune ſhall I be placed! The independence bequeathed me by my grandfather I have turned to good account. What, though it has been the means of effecting the ruin of a few thoughtleſs profligates? There vices were incurable, and they would have been as completely beggared by the ſkilful operations of others if all my thoughts had been engaged in the exerciſe of devotion, and my guineas appropriated to charitable donations—Nay, to preſerve my eſtimation with the world, I have raiſed from the earth thoſe whom others, leſs mindful of opinion, would have left groveling in miſery.—Pſha! when I ſcrutinize my conduct with an eye half inclined to condemnation, I find matter for praiſe inſtead of cenſure. Dupes will be dupes—Knaves will make their prey of them—and lucky is the dupe that becomes the prey of a knave with ſome conſcience, and a great regard for a good reputation. Whom have we here?

div.stage: Enter SHARPSET, dreſſed as a Methodiſt Preacher.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Peace be unto this houſe!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Who is this? With what Hedge Divine have I the honour of an acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Thy name is Leonard Viſorly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what is your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: To diſcourſe with thee on the ſtate of thy conſcience.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I requeſt you will ſave yourſelf that trouble: my conſcience is a charge of which I chooſe to have the ſole guardianſhip.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: But it is my duty to inquire whether thou haſt treated that precious charge like unto a faithful guardian—Whether thou haſt not ſtained with guilt, that which was conſigned to thy care ſpotleſs and pure; and which now goads thee with complainings for thy iniquity. Therefore, I ſay—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You ſhall ſay no more in this houſe. Out with you directly (offering to puſh him out).

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh, Leonard, Leonard, is this the way you treat an old friend, after ſo long an abſence?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: An old friend!—What do you mean? Who are you?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: And ſo, my reverend appearance has concealed from your recognition your friend, and brother in iniquity, Jeremy Sharpſet!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Sharpſet!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But what is the meaning of this transformation?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: The reſtleſſneſs of my diſpoſition, and inclination for any purſuit in preference to laudable exertion, and honeſt induſtry.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: You always had a propenſity to confeſs your faults.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.q: Yes, but not much propenſity to amend them. To be ſure I ſhewed a little diſpoſition towards it by quitting you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: Your moſt humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I am afraid you felt the loſs of me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes, I confeſs it—You were very ſerviceable.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Yes, I was. I did the roguery, and you received the profits.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Come, come—You were not ill paid.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh, no—I don't complain. How is poor Drooply?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Still the creature of my bounty.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Well, that is kind of you—A generous weakneſs in your character—You ſwindled him out of two thouſand a year, and are good enough to allow him a hundred. Ah, you are a model of philanthropy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Come, a truce with your ſarcaſm.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Ah, bleſs your honeſt tender heart! He is as grateful to you as ever, I conclude.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes, he eſteems me his friend and preſerver.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Poor fellow! "He was wont to ſet the table in a roar, now quite chop-fallen." I declare I never think of him but with a heart-ache.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, well—but what have you been doing ſince we parted?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: All ſorts of things I ought not to do. To confeſs the truth, the reaſon I quitted you, was, I was tired of the work you chalked out for me—You wanted to puſh me a little farther in roguery than I liked. I am but a petty larceny villain—That ruin of poor Drooply, in which I was the chief engine for you—that hit me hard. I am fooliſh enough to have qualms. I know you deſpiſe me for it; but we all have our weakneſſes.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, well; but what became of you?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I'll tell you. I had unluckily, once in my life, dined at a Lord Mayor's feaſt.—I ſhall never forget it. Talk of Earls and Dukes entertaining!—Pſha! a rivulet to the ocean. Ever after I panted for City honours—So, all my honeſt earnings I was determined to depoſit in trade. An opportunity ſoon offered—I was to become a ſleeping partner in a great houſe. I paid down my caſh to the laſt guinea—A docket was ſtruck againſt the firm the very next week, ſo the poor ſleeping partner had nothing but the open air for his ſlumbers; and, inſtead of being in the road to claim a ſeat at a Guildhall dinner, I had ſcarcely enough to purchaſe one in Porridge Iſland.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: So, all your hopes of a gold chain vaniſhed?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Yes; and I was in a very likely way to be adorned with an iron one;—but I was reſolved to take myſelf out of the reach of temptation and danger, by leaving London.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: In what capacity did you travel?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Still I had a taſte for partnerſhip. I engaged with a very reſpectable Gentleman to divide with him the attention and profits of—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: A collection of wild beaſts.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I gueſs you were not a ſleeping partner here.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: No; my companions were rather hoſtile to repoſe. Not much liking ſuch uncivilized ſociety, and being a little apprehenſive that my fellow-travellers might one time or other make a ſupper of me, I ſoon cut this connection; and inſtead of exhibiting the merits of others, I got a taſte for diſplaying my own.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: How, pray?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I joined a party of ſtrolling players.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I know you muſt be ſhocked at my deſcending ſo damn'd low as to turn actor. But I did not diſgrace myſelf long.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: How happened that?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: The audience would not let me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I came out in Richard the Third. I thought it deviliſh fine; but the good folks in the front thought otherwiſe. I ranted—they hooted—However, I out-roared them, and puſhed on till I got into Boſworth Field—"A horſe, a horſe! my kingdom for a horſe!" When a drunken, Foxhunting ſquire (I ſhall never loſe the ſound of his damn'd voice) bawled out of the boxes, that I ſhould have the beſt horſe in his ſtable, if I would ride away directly, and never come back again.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: The actor's warn'd me it would not do. I thought it envy in them, and have ſome reaſon to think they ſent in a party to hiſs me. However, by way of comfort, they told me, though I ſhould never act tragedy, they thought I ſhould ſucceed in low comedy—Low comedy! only think of their impudence! Is this a face for low comedy? No, no, damn it! I could not ſtoop to that.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, your next reſource?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh, then I got a call, and mounted the habiliments in which you ſee me; this was lucrative; but my conſcience would not ſuffer me any longer to drain from the pockets of the poor, the earnings of their induſtry: nay, what is worſe, embitter their innocent minds with groundleſs terrors, and inſpire them with prejudice againſt their fellow-creatures.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: So then you deign at laſt to return to me.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Yes; for I had rather cheat the rich, than delude the poor.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll endeavour to find you employment.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: That I don't doubt, as long as there is a pigeon to be plucked, and as I am diſpoſed to be a rook at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No, I have at preſent honeſter objects in view, to attain which I may need your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Well, I'm glad of that; for, upon my ſoul, I am tired of being a rogue.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: If I reach the point of my preſent aim, I may, myſelf, relinquiſh that character. I ſhall then have wealth enough to gratify even my ambition. I am no further a knave than as it forwards my grand purſuit, the attainment of wealth. And who would not uſe any means to gain that, which covers vice with the garb of reſpect, and without which virtue meets but pity or deriſion.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Well obſerved; and never was obſervation more patly illuſtrated. You are a glorious inſtance of the firſt part of your ſentiment, and here comes a proof of the latter.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Ah, Drooply, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: How do you do, my dear fellow?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Where have you hid yourſelf? nobody has ſeen you of late?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I have been ſtriving to follow the example of my acquaintances, and learning to be as ſhy of them as they are of me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Why, what an altered being you are! you uſed to be a merry fellow.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes, for I uſed to be a rich fellow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Come, come, cheer up. Good ſpirits are a man's beſt friends.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Ay; but like the reſt of his friends, when his money leaves him, they leave him too.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Nay, nay; your friends have not all deſerted you.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: All but you. There is not another man in the world who would care a ſtraw if the devil had one.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: If you are ſo deſpondent, I muſt recommend you a ſpiritual comforter. Can your reverence adminiſter conſolation to this afflicted being? (to Sharpſet.)

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: No; for I can't return him the money I won of him.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: What, not remember me! If I had done you a kindneſs, I might expect to be forgotten▪ but I thought every one remembered an ill-turn.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: In this pious paſtor you behold a quondam acquaintance, Mr. Sharpſet.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What! Sharpſet turned Methodiſt?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Yes; but don't wrong my underſtanding—Only from neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You might triumph now, if you were diſpoſed to indulge ſpleen; for the man who was the chief gainer by your loſſes at play, is now as low in the world as yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: No, I am ſo completely without gratification, I have not even the comfort a malicious diſpoſition would afford me. It is far from a relief to me, to ſee another unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You are mutually diſtreſſed; yet, how differently you bear your misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p:
That is eaſily accounted for. I have a thouſand reſources—Drooply has none. Born to no other inheritance, I have learned to turn to account
what I inherit from nature; ſo that, tho' my acquiſitions have been ſquandered, I am ſtill in poſſeſſion of my original patrimony.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Ah, you lucky dog! you have an eſtate in every corner of your brain, and a pretty income at the end of every finger. Now, the whole produce of my ſkull would not get me change for ſixpence: and as for my hands, curſe them! they are fit for nothing but to dangle by my ſides, or ſtuff out my coat-pockets.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Why, I am afraid they will never fill your pockets with any thing but themſelves.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Oh I wiſh I had been a Turk!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: A Turk!

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes, a Turk: they are the only wiſe people on earth: they teach all their great men ſome honeſt employment.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Do they? I know ſome great men I wiſh they would give a leſſon to.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Oh if we had that good muſſulman cuſtom among us, how many a rich man would be of more uſe to ſociety when his eſtate was gone, than while he poſſeſſed it! as a good cobler is a more valuable character than a rich man who does not employ his wealth properly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Why, you are turning moraliſt!

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p:
Yes; the loſs of wealth ſeldom leſſens a man's morality. While I am creeping about, ſuch a piece of moving lumber, what reſpect I feel for every reputable tinker that comes in my way. This very morning how I did envy a merry rogue of a ſhoeblack! With what glee he put the poliſh of an artiſt on the boot he was blacking: how merrily he bruſhed and ſung, and how conceitedly and happily he looked at his work when he had done it! Oh, you jolly dog, thought I, what a happy man had been ſpoiled, if you had been born
to two thouſand a year! you would never have enjoyed the luxury of poliſhing a ſhoe, or the independent exultation of exiſting by your own induſtry.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We muſt endeavour to diſpel your melancholy. You are a martyr to ennui. I muſt find you employment.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: You muſt do ſomething beſide—find me capacity.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: That you don't want. Your talents have been only ſlumbering.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Hav'n't they? they have had a pretty long nap, and a ſound one too. I'm afraid it will be a hard matter to wake them.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I don't deſpair; eſpecially when I ſhall ſet the loud voice of friendſhip to rouſe them.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: If they don't wake at that call, you may take your oath their ſlumber is everlaſting. But tho' I am maſter of this poor tenement, I really am ſo ignorant of the ſtate of the upper ſtory, as not to know whether the inhabitants have periſhed by neglect, or are only dozing from want of employment; but this I do know, there is a lively fellow in the firſt floor (pointing to his heart) who would dance with joy to do you the ſlighteſt ſervice, and loſe every drop of blood to prove his friendſhip and gratitude. [Exeunt.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: SCENE I.—An Apartment in Viſorly's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, I have not been in town above half an hour.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Have you brought with you from the country houſe the box, which, I told you, contains the writings of your property.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes—ſhall I give it to you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No; I am too buſy at preſent—Only take care of it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, my dear brother, I am ſo glad we are to have our houſe full of company—Oh, that is delightful! How I do love a racketting, noiſy ſcene! In a morning the faſhionable buſtle of Bondſtreet, the muſical thunder of a footman's rap—the dealing out tickets to the whole ton-world—and then at night, driving to twenty different aſſemblies—ſeeing the whole world in the courſe of an evening—Oh, dear, dear, what a charming age to live in! we ſee more of life in one day, than our anceſtors did in their whole exiſtence.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes; but I doubt whether we are the happier for it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To be ſure we are. What is all this but happineſs? care can never reach us, for in all this hurry nobody has time to think; and you know it is thinking makes one unhappy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Well, I'm not Cynic enough to attempt to reaſon people out of their notions of happineſs; for as it exiſts in imagination, the idea is the
reality. But, my dear Caroline, I have told you my wiſh to be thought well of by this young Eaſt Indian. From living in the ſame houſe, and being nearly of an age, you will moſt likely contract a friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes; and her taking my brother for her lover, will be the beſt ſecurity for that friendſhip; for then, we can't be rivals—and nothing is ſo apt to make young ladies diſagree, as being both of the ſame mind.

sp.speaker: Old VISORLY
sp.p: This way, Mrs. Cleveland.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.p: Here comes the mother.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. CLEVELAND, Lady JEMIMA and old VISORLY.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Believe me, madam, we experience the greateſt pleaſure in welcoming you to this houſe. My daughter, madam—my ſon, Leonard.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I feel extreme happineſs in the event of this moment, which makes me known to you, madam. Suffer me to aſſure you, that if I can be the humble inſtrument of rendering you a ſervice, I ſhall eſteem it the greateſt bliſs of my life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: I hope, madam, we ſhall be able to make your reſidence here, not entirely diſagreeable to you: our friends and connections, among whom, I am proud to ſay, are ſome of the firſt rank, will, I am ſure, do their poſſible to ſecond our poor endeavours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p:
Your kindneſs, madam, merits my warmeſt return of gratitude. The endearing attentions with which you honour me, will tend to ſoothe the terrors of a mind anxious for the ſafety
of the dear objects on which all its future happineſs depends.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: With what ſincere joy, madam, I conſider how ſhort will be the continuance of your apprehenſions, and how complete the happineſs you will ſo ſoon poſſeſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Heaven grant it! I have paſſed many a tedious year with no other ſolace than the hope of what now appears ſo near me. Fifteen years' abſence from the huſband of my affections, and from my dear child, has been a period, you may well conceive, barren of comfort:—and, even now, I have much to dread—a long and dangerous voyage.—But I will hope the beſt, and not wrong Providence, by doubting its goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: I am out of breath—quite out of breath—And I am almoſt out of my wits—ſhe is arrived! ſhe is arrived!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: My daughter!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Yes—I have ſeen her, I have ſeen her!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: O good heaven!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: I have—Ah, the ſweet little dear! and not ſo little either—She is quite a woman. Ah bleſs her! I've had a kiſs, and I'll have another—I beg pardon gentlefolks—if I'm unmannerly 'tis joy makes me ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: In this very houſe by this time. Oh here ſhe comes! here ſhe comes!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: My child! Oh, my ſweet child!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My mother!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: How have I longed for this bleſt moment! But your dear father, did you leave him well?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes—quite well—And eager for the happineſs which I feel now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: My ſweet, ſweet Julia! How well am I repaid for my paſt years of miſery! Oh, height of bliſs! The mother claſps once more in her fond arms, her long loſt, only child.— (to the company.) Pardon theſe tranſports—Joy like mine will keep no limits.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We all participate too much in your felicity to wiſh repreſſed ſuch exquiſite emotions.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Yes, madam, we all feel boundleſs joy. What a pretty little creature it is, Leonard—Oh, you will be a happy rogue!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: My Julia, to theſe generous friends we owe the utmoſt gratitude; their kindneſs grants us an aſylum while your father ſhall remain from us.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis for us to be grateful, for your kind compliance with our wiſhes (croſſing to Julia.) Tho' we can't rival the ſplendour of Calcutta, I hope London will have ſome charms for you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh yes, I find already it has every charm: for I'm with my mother, and with friends who look as if they loved me.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: And who that ſets eyes on you, can help loving you, you dear, pretty creature? I beg pardon, gentlefolks.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Who is that good old gentleman? You can't think how glad he was to ſee me: he kiſſed me as fondly as if I had been his own daughter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: He is one, my Julia, who has made my comfort for theſe fifteen years the chief buſineſs of his life.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What, has he been ſo kind to my dear mother? Oh then I muſt kiſs him again.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: I am too happy—I am too happy!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Tho' my new friends are ſo kind to me, I muſt not forget thoſe who have loved me before. Where is Gangica?

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Here, my dear miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Mother you muſt love Gangica for my ſake; ſhe has leſt her country and all her relations, becauſe ſhe would not part from me: therefore I muſt love her better than ever, and every body that loves me, muſt love Gangica.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Her affection for my dear child makes her certain of my love. But I feel exhauſted with exceſs of joy. We ſhould not lament that there are few incidents in life, which waken ſuch extreme delight; for were they frequent, how ſhortly would our weak frames yield to the tumults of ecſtacy!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Let me conduct you, madam, to your apartments.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: You are all goodneſs. Come, my dear child.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Lady JEMIMA, Mrs. CLEVELAND, JULIA, CAROLINE and GANGICA

div.stage: Manent LEONARD, Old VISORLY and OAKWORTH.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: (looking after them, then wiping his eyes.) I can't tell how it is—I be no whimperer, gentlemen; but ſomehow, my eyes do nothing but moiſten to-day.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p:
I feel the tear of ſenſibility bedew my
cheek. Ah, Leonard, my boy, if you can but get her.— (aſide to Leonard.)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Huſh, ſir, huſh! (to Oakworth.) Wha delight, ſir, you muſt feel at the happineſs of this family, to whom you have ſhewn ſo much attachment! What gratitude do they not owe you!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Gratitude to me! That is a great miſtake of yours, and it behoves me to ſet you right. Mrs. Cleveland's father ſaved me once from ruin—me and my family from beggary; and I think he muſt have but a bad notion of the value of a kindneſs done him, who, if he could live long enough, would not ſtrive to repay it down to the fiftieth generation.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What a noble heart!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Noble heart! Pſha, pſha! ſure the world is not ſo bad that a man need be praiſed for not being a monſter.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I am proud of the happineſs of being known to you.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: And ſo am I, moſt ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Why to be ſure a mighty matter to be proud of, gentlemen, being known to an old ſtupid country bumpkin. Surely you be jeering a body—but if you be, I can't find in my heart to be angry; for as long as you are ſo good and ſo kind to the dear creatures I love, you may flout and jeer at me as much as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You miſtake us extremely: it is the fartheſt from our thoughts to be deficient in any particle of reſpect.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.q: Oh dear! we never dreamed of ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.q:
Well, I ſuppoſe I ſhall be able in time to underſtand your London ſpeechifying; but in truth your fine civil ſayings are ſo like making
game, that, for a little while, I ſhall be deucedly puzzled.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You never can be at a loſs for our meaning—We feel the value of ſuch integrity as yours; and be aſſured we ſhall always ſay leſs of your merits, than we think you deſerve.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Always leſs than you deſerve.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Do you know I ſhall take that very kind of you—for if you are ſo good as to fancy I have any deſerts at all, you muſt in conſcience think they be very little—And if ſo be you keep your word, and ſay leſs than you think, I ſhall be mighty happy—becauſe then, you will juſt ſay nothing at all. So, gentlemen, as in duty bound, I am your moſt humble ſervant. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.q: Poor old fellow—Age begins to make havock—the upper works are giving way.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: Ah, ſir! how few like you, enjoy in advanced life, robuſtneſs of form, vigour of intellect,—in ſhort, all the advantages of youth, without its inexperience.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.q: Very few indeed, Leonard—I am one out of five thouſand.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: Years in you, ſir, have only juſt ſlackened the blazing fire of youth.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.q: Yes—ſlackened—not extinguiſhed it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: This old ruſtic, ſir, appears to ſtand vaſtly well with the mother; I muſt endeavour to gain his good graces; for the ſentiments of a man ſhe has known ſo long, and eſteems ſo highly, muſt have great weight with her.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Very true—I'll take care to pay him vaſt attention. I'll do your buſineſs with him—I'll cajole the old fool.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; but be cautious leſt your partial affection for me ſhould make you too laviſh in my panegyric.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Do you think I don't know how to get round ſuch a ſilly old bumpkin? leave me to wheedle him—I'll do it cunningly, ſhrewdly, Leonard—wiſely, my boy. [Exit OLD VISORLY.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Now the game is ſtarted, I muſt ſet my whole pack full cry for the chace. Here comes my prime agent in knavery, Sharpſet. Having uſed him ſo eſſentially in the plunder of Drooply, and that buſineſs completed, I could have diſpenſed with his return; for no intercourſe is ſo grating as that which ſubſiſts with a confederate in villainy. However, to keep him in my power, I have ſtill contrived to keep him in my debt; ſo that I need not fear him, and he has talents to render him ſtill uſeful to me.

div.p: I am glad to find you return'd to the laity. I would rather ſee knavery wear any garb than that of religion.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Your reaſon for which, is, that then only you are afraid of its being an overmatch for you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Not ſo; but that I have not ceaſed to reſpect, tho' I have dared to violate.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Heyday! I believe you congratulate me on laying down the trade of preaching, becauſe you mean to take it up. But it tells well for morality, that even ſome knaves can admire the cauſe, which honeſt men are riſking their lives to defend. But, a truce to this ſtyle, for it ſits awkwardly upon us. Your viſitors, I find, are arrived.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes; and the girl is beautiful as an angel.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh, a divinity!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Why, have you ſeen her?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Then, whence theſe raptures?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Did not you tell me ſhe was heireſs to half a million?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh! your ſervant—but I aſſure you her intrinſic worth—

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Can be nothing to her ſterling worth.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I am convinced I feel ſomething like love.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: To be ſure you do. I ſhould adore a twentieth part of the ſum, if it were in the pocket of the uglieſt old harridan that ever was ducked for a witch.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You ſeem to hold beauty very cheap.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh no—I only value money very highly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But when they are combined—

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: That is always poſſible—Whoever has the money, need not be long without the beauty.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: In one object I hope to poſſeſs the ultimatum of my wiſhes in both. It muſt now be my • are to have all around her impreſſed with eſteem for me—my eulogium wafted to her on every breath, cannot fail of infuſing a favourable prepoſſeſſion. Be you mindful, that on all occaſions your report of me may ſwell the gale of approbation. I need not tell you that your intereſt will be no ſufferer by your panegyric.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: And I aſſure you I am ſo good natur'd a fellow, that, make it equally profitable to me, and I would rather ſpeak in a man's praiſe than againſt him—So much am I unlike the greater part of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: The chief perſonage I wiſh to enliſt in my favour, is an old ruſtic, much devoted to the family, and ranking high in the mother's eſteem. His name is Oakworth.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oakworth.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oak—Oak—worth.—Where does he come from?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: With Mrs Cleveland from Warwickſhire. What ſurpriſes you?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh nothing—Only it ſtrikes me, I have heard that name before.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Be earneſt to throw yourſelf in his way▪ and remember by diſcreetly applied praiſe, • o pave my paſſage to the eſteem I deſire. To merit eſteem is at beſt a tedious method of obtaining it—The purchaſed diploma equally gives the title, and ſaves the labour of deſerving it. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: So, I am to throw myſelf in the way of this old ruſtic, Oakworth—You little gueſs, my very worthy friend, what you are directing—To throw myſelf in the way of no leſs intereſting a perſonage to me than my identical dad—my own natural father. It is now a long while ſince I ſaw the good old boy:—I was but fourteen, I think, when it entered my mad head to ſcamper away from him—A project well worthy of ſo experienced an age. That frolic has thrown me into many a ſituation which would be whimſical to relate—Yes, and many a ſituation it would not be prudent to relate. I long to have a glimpſe of the old buck. I wonder whether he would know me—Whom have we got here? Oh! this is one of the Aſiatic importations.

div.stage: Enter GANGICA, looking about with curioſity; on ſeeing SHARPSET, ſhe ſtarts back.
div.p: Don't be fright'ned, my dear—I am very tame.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: You not hurt me?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p:
Lord love you, not I. I ſuppoſe ſhe
thought I ſhou'd dart at her like one of her native tygers. I aſſure you, my dear, I ſha'n't bite.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: No, no; but you may do great deal miſchief, and not bite.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: But I won't do any miſchief at all.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Dat's good man. You not wonder I am afraid—I am ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſign ſo by your being afraid; for, were you not a ſtranger you would know that nobody in this country has the power of wronging another with impunity. Beſide, your being a ſtranger, is a ſure title to protection.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: O den, dis be very good country. Glad I come here.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: And ſo am I, glad you are come here, my little marigold.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: What for you glad I come here?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Becauſe I like the look of you.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Oh, you mock—You not like my copper face.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Why not, my dear? In my mind a lady looks better with a face of copper, than of braſs—And that is all the faſhion.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Oh, if my face were like my dear Miſs Julia's! Oh ſhe ſo pretty! ſhe ſo good!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: And you love her very much?

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Ay, dat I do—I would die for her.—Oh, I would do great deal more—I would live to bear pain in my limbs, and ſorrow in my heart, to make her happy.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p:
Well ſaid, my little diſciple of Brama! If the hallowed waves of the Ganges had any ſhare in infuſing this gratitude, I wiſh its ſtream lay near enough to be reſorted to as a faſhionable bathing place. This little ſun-burnt favourite may do Leonard ſervice—I'll try to retain her in his cauſe.
(aſide.) I know who loves your young lady very much.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Ay!—who?

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Every body.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Yes, yes;—but there is a gentleman here, in this houſe—a young handſome gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Yes. (with a little titter.)

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Very handſome.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Yes,—very handſome.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: What, you have ſeen him?

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Yes,—I ſee him now.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: (looking about) Who?

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Why, handſome—very handſome gentleman. (looking in his face.)

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Meaning me—This girl's ſimplicity has done more than all the bronze of her ſex could ever accompliſh—wonderful to relate—made me bluſh.—I had no notion tho' that theſe natives of Indoſtan had ſo much taſte. But, my dear, I am not the only handſome gentleman in this houſe—I mean another, who has conceived a great eſteem for your young lady; and your good opinion of him will, I know, give him great ſatisfaction—and ſo—but I had better have done with talking, and appeal to the rhetoric of all times, and all nations (taking out a purſe) you muſt know, my dear, that this gentleman is very generous—and I am ſure he will be highly pleaſed at my making you a preſent from him of this little purſe. (gives her the purſe.)

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: But what for you give me dis.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Why, that—that you may ſpeak well of this young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: How I ſpeak well of him I not know?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Um—But when you do know him—

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p:
Den, if he good man, I ſpeak well of him widout dis—if he bad man, I not ſpeak well
of him for whole ſhip-full of money. (returns the purſe.)

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: So, ſo,—my friend Leonard will not be able to buy his diploma here. There is ſomething mighty faſcinating in this duſky piece of diſintereſtedneſs. Since I find we are not likely to come to a right underſtanding as agents, I'll try how we can agree as principals. Pray, my dear, have you left your heart in India?

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: No—my heart in de right place. (pointing to it.)

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I'll anſwer for that—'Tis in the right place I am ſure. But you have not reſolved never to love any body?

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: No—I love great many.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: The deuce you do!

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Yes; my young lady I love dearly, dearly. And I love every body dat love her.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh, is that all? But all your love ſeems to belong to your lady. Can't you love a little on your own account?

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: What you ſay?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Why, you have not made a vow to die a maid.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: I never make vows—it is wicked.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Very well—why then, if I were to be very fond of you.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Would you be fond of me?

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: I not know.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Becauſe, tho' your face white and pretty, I not know if your mind ſo.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Why, that's true, my love—But you may take my word for it.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: No, no—not take man's word when he praiſe himſelf.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Well, how are you to know.

sp.speaker: Gang.
sp.p: Why, in great, long time—if I find you do all good—not one bit of bad.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh Lord—Oh Lord—Oh Lord! here is a trial of gallantry! here is a teſt for a lover!

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Well, good bye—I ſtay too long while with you. My lady want me, may be. I ſee you again ſometime.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, I hope ſo.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Good bye, good bye. [Exit GANGICA.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I am afraid I ſtand but a poor chance of ſucceſs here. It is not very likely that my little Gentoo's ſyſtem for chooſing a lover ſhould come into faſhion—But if it ſhould, Lord, Lord, what a different claſs of beings the favourites of the ladies would be! no—yes—'tis he—my papa, by all that's miraculous! Oh the deuce—what a buſineſs here will be!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Whew, whew,—plague take it! I never was ſo tired with riding a whole day after the Fox, as I am now with half an hours plaguy palaver from this old maſter of the houſe. He may be a very good ſort of man—which I don't doubt; but he be curſed tireſome. Who be this • ine ſpark? ſervant, ſir.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: How do you do—how do you do? (hiding his face with his handkerchief.)

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Pretty well; at your ſervice. Poor gentleman, he have got the tooth-ach, I believe▪ I am afraid you feel uncomfortable, ſir.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I do, upon my ſoul, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Are you often attacked in this way?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: No, ſir, I have not been attacked in this way, for a great many years.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Dear, dear! what, you be quite taken by ſurprize?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Never more ſo in my life, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Well, ſir, but I hope you will ſoon get rid of ſo troubleſome a companion.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: And as you ſeem to be very uneaſy, it will be but kind in me to keep you company a bit.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: If you ſtay with me, how the devil am I to get rid of my troubleſome companion? (aſide) Oh Lord, Oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: You ſeem to be in huge great pain. I would not be plagued in this way. I would get ſomebody to lug him out.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh how I wiſh ſomebody would be ſo kind!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: If I could borrow a pair of pinchers, I would do it for you in a moment—I have drawn fifty ſo in our village.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh! I could not think of troubling you.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: It will be a pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: No, by no means—I think I am rather better.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Ah! the fear of the tug always makes it leave off aching. But you'd better have him out—he'll plague you again.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I am afraid he will, but I muſt bear it▪ He doesn't know my voice, and my face and perſon muſt be ſtill more altered—Hang it, I'll e'en try (takes his handkerchief from his face by degrees) I begin to feel eaſier, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Heartily glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: (Takes it quiet away.) My face is rather enlarged, ſir. (feeling it as though it were ſwelled).

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Um! I ſee no ſwelling at all—Ah! you were more frightened than hurt.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: So it turns out, ſir—for he has not the ſlighteſt remembrance of me (aſide). Upon my ſoul, it was very kind of you to offer to operate—and for an entire ſtranger too.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.q: One ſhould be ready to lend every body a lift.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Yes—and a pretty lift you would have given to my poor grinders.—But how came you to underſtand drawing teeth?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Oh, in a little village; a man that means to do good to his neighbours, muſt turn his hand to every thing. Why, I have bled folks aforenow.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: That has run in the family. I have bled 'em a little too, (aſide). Well, Sir, and I dare ſay you have a good dame at home who is as ready to aſſiſt her neighbours as you are?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Why, yes; my old girl don't grudge ſtirring her ſtumps when there is any good to be done.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear the good old dame is alive. Now, I'll venture to touch on a tender ſubject (aſide). Any—any ſons and daughters?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: No—no; they be all gone (ſighing.)

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: What—none leſt?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: No, no—Yes—one, mayhap—one may be alive—one ungracious boy—No, no; it be hardly poſſible, though there is a chance, a little chance—I have always kept a watch on the Old Bailey Seſſions Papers, and the County Aſſize liſts—and to be ſure I never found his name down in them; but there is little certainty or comfort in that—for you know, my poor wicked boy may have been hanged, or ſent to Botany Bay under ſome other name.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Hanged, or ſent to Botany Bay!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Ah! ſir, it grieves my heart to think it—but he had ſuch little ſharping tricks about him when he was but a child, that I were forced to laſh, and laſh, every day of my life. I dare ſay, if he be alive, he have got my well-meant marks on his back to this day.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Really! It aches at the recollection. (aſide).

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Yes—you muſt ſuppoſe I had his well doing at heart—and ſo I never ſpared him. I did hope, by good advice, and good example, and a good horſewhip, all together, to have made an honeſt man of him—But the rogue ſcampered away when he was but a younker, and ſo got looſe into the wide wicked world, with a bad diſpoſition, and neceſſity to whet it. You muſt needs think as I do, about what is become of him.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I really think, ſir, you judge too ſeverely of your ſon, Je—What is your ſon's name, ſir?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Jeremy.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: O, ſir, take comfort—Many a lad with as bad a beginning has turned out a great man.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Ay, a great man, mayhap—but I am afraid nobody with ſo bad a beginning has turned out a good one.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, you can't think how it ſhocks me that you ſhould judge ſo harſhly of a child of your own. I dare ſwear no more harm has happend to Jerry than there has to me.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: O dear, O dear! it be quite a different caſe.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Not at all—not at all—A caſe very much in point, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: How be that? Why, were you a bit of a rogue when you were a younker?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: To own the truth to you, my dear ſir, (but don't mention it) I was.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Ah! but you never ran away from your home.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: You don't ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Honour.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Yes, yes; but you ſoon ſaw your error, and went back to your father?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: So far from it, my good ſir, that it was many years before we met.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: And, then, quite by accident.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Really!

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Yes; and the beſt joke was, he did not know me.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Not know you! Oh the old fool!—Beg pardon, ſir, for making ſo free with your father.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: No apology. Pray make as free with him as you pleaſe. Was it not droll?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Deviliſh droll—Ha, ha, ha! I can't help laughing. So, you met him, and he did not know you?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: No—he did not know me.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Well, and what did he ſay when he did know you?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Why, that, my dear ſir, I muſt defer telling you till another opportunity.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Well, Sir, whenever you pleaſe—I long to hear the reſt.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Depend upon it, ſir, it won't be concealed from you. Good day to you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Good bye, ſir. Ha, ha, ha! only think of your own father's not knowing you, ha, ha▪ ha!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But you ſurely won't ſtay at home this evening too?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes, indeed I had rather.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You have the moſt unaccountable domeſtic propenſity. Has novelty no pleaſure for you?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis novelty makes me domeſtic; a dear novelty, the novelty of a mother. Now I have gained her ſweet ſociety, ſhould I reſign it for frivolous amuſements I can command at all times?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, you are a dear, good girl.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But where are you going this evening?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That I cannot tell without referring to my engagement liſt; but as near as I can gueſs, to about a dozen aſſemblies, the opera, a concert, and a maſqued ball.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My dear Caroline, you'll be fatigued to death.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh, no. I am never weary with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And do you often make theſe laborious exertions for your amuſement?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh, yes, all through the ſeaſon—And I don't think that half long enough.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well, to be equal to ſuch efforts, a woman of faſhion muſt be endued with more ſtrength than any creature in the univerſe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
To be ſure. Your elephant is nothing to
her; for groveling inſtinct reſtrains him from exceeding the paltry limits of mere corporeal exertion; but the elevated ſpirits, and glowing imagination of a woman of faſhion make her a being all eſſence—She is like the wind, light, fleet, and invincible.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And is ſhe not ſometimes like the wind in my native country, which now breathes all gentleneſs, yet, in a few hours will whirl a whole fortune to deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why, yes, I am afraid there have been inſtances of the tornado kind. I really don't know whether many men may not be better pleaſed with your quiet ſtay-at-home notions, than with more daſh and ſpirit; but perhaps you never yet examined your inclinations with an eye to how a huſband would approve them. Ah, Julia, you bluſh, my dear; I believe this ſcrutiny has not been unattended to.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How you talk!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes. I talk, and you think; but both on the ſame ſubject. My dear girl, have I yet claim enough on your confidence to aſk, if the being I allude to has ſtolen into your dreams, and been admitted into your waking reveries in the form of a beautiful accompliſhed youth, whoſe exact likeneſs you have never yet realized, or have you already aſſigned him "A local habitation and a name?"

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Heigho!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh, then I lay my life Mr. Heigho has a name and place of abode. Am I not right?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And in what quarter of the globe does he exiſt?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Nay, where ſhou'd he? I have not been
long enough in this country to have found him here. I muſt have met him before.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: (aſide). So, my poor brother, your chance is gone. What is his name?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Henry Melville.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And you expect him here, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh, yes, in the ſame veſſel with my father.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And does he know your partiality?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes, and I know his for me; and my father approves.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh, you happy girl! Now, the man I love neither knows my partiality for him; nor do I know whether he cares at all for me—And if we did know that we cared for each other, I am ſure my father would let us care on till both our hearts broke, before he would give his conſent.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Becauſe the poor dear fellow has loſt all his fortune; but luckily my father's conſent is not eſſential, as I have a fortune independent of him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then you are not in a very hopeleſs ſtate?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh, yes, I am: for my lover (my love I ſhould ſay) loſt all ſelf-importance with his fortune; and I very much fear I ſhall never be able to make him comprehend that a young woman with a good eſtate is ready to let him be maſter of it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hints won't do—And if I could bring myſelf to ſay to him plainly, "Dear Sir, I adore you!" he would only think I was making a jeſt of him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Drooply to wait on you, Ma'am. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Lord, how my heart beats; Julia, my dear girl, this is the very man.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then, my ſweet Caroline, you can very well diſpenſe with me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh, no—pray don't go.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You would be very angry if I took you at your word. Adieu! [Exit JULIA.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Will this provoking creature for ever give me the trouble of making love to him without underſtanding me?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes; but I will go away again if I intrude.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay! did not I ſend for you?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: So I underſtood.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And why do you give me the trouble? You made your viſits formerly without being ſent for.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Did I? Yes. I dare ſay I was a very troubleſome fellow.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay, you found thoſe viſits always received with pleaſure; therefore, it is ſtrange you need be reminded to continue them.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: My viſits received with pleaſure! Ah, this is the way in which you always uſed to banter me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Banter you! Stupidity!

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes, yes. I know you are at your old tricks. You were always cutting your jokes at me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p:
Yes, you; and I remember I uſed to laugh at them; but that was when my pockets were full. Upon my ſoul, I can't now. No, no,
you muſt excuſe me. I defy a man to laugh at a joke when he has loſt all his money.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You ſtrange creature! Do you know that I have been thinking of you a great deal lately?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes, I don't doubt it—to play me ſome trick or other.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Silly animal! (aſide) I have been even dreaming of you—Do you ever dream of me?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I could not think of taking ſuch a liberty.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Provoking! Oh, I had almoſt forgot—I knew I had ſomething particular to tell you. It was whiſpered to me t'other night at Lady Blab's, that you—(now mind, if it is true, I ſhan't be angry) that you had told ſome friend in confidence (now mind, I have promiſed not to be angry) that you were in love.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I told ſome friend?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes; and that delicacy, occaſioned by the loſs of your fortune had prevented you from declaring your paſſion to the object of it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I never—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now do ſtop a moment; but that if you thought it would be favourably received (—now remember I have promiſed not to be angry—) you would overcome your diffidence, and reveal it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I aſſure you that—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A moment's patience pray—At laſt, by great entreaty, I learnt the lady's name.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And what was it?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Need you be told—it was—Caroline Viſorly.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul it is a trumped-up ſtory from beginning to end.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Incorrigible ſtupidity!

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Beg pardon—did not know company was here (going).

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If you want any thing, you need not run away, child.
sp.stage: (Gangica goes up to a table where ſome work lies.)
sp.p: Well, ſir, I have no more to ſay—Only don't entirely relinquiſh the ſociety of one, to whom yours ever was, and ever will be, a pleaſure. Adieu!

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Now who the devil can have told ſuch a curſed pack of lies of me—All done to ruin me in her good opinion. That I, a poor undone dog, with not a ſixpence in the world but what I receive from her brother's friendſhip—I might ſay his—charity, ſhould preſume to cheriſh hopes of Caroline Viſorly. No, no—all my hopes of her vaniſhed with my fortune. I love her—I do love her; and what a good-natured ſoul it is not to have flown into a rage at ſuppoſing I could be guilty of ſuch vanity—ſuch preſumption, ſuch folly—Ay, that—that ſaved me:—knowing the folly, ſhe pardoned the preſumption.
sp.stage: [Gangica has been at the table getting her work, and comes forward with it in her hand.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: You happy, very happy man.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Oh yes, my dear, very, very— (hardly attending to her).

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Bleſs me—but you not look, you not ſpeak like happy man.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And pray, my little dear, what ſhould make you ſuppoſe I am a happy man?

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Becauſe pretty lady love you.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Pretty lady love me! Why, even little • awny muſt cut a joke at me.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Yes; pretty lady dat went out juſt now love you.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Oh, I am known for a butt by inſtinct. I have not a doubt but it would be the ſame all the world over. If I were to land at Otaheite, the natives would begin quizzing me directly in their damn'd gibberiſh. Why, you are a comical little rogue. So, that lady loves me, does ſhe?

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: You'd find it hard to make me believe that.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: And you find it much more great deal harder make me believe ſhe not love you.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Yes; ſhe not make me believe herſelf if ſhe ſay ſhe not love you.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: No;—becauſe dey tell me dat always tell true.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: They? Who are they?

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Deſe— (pointing to her eyes). Truth not always come from here (the mouth), always from here (her eyes).

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Hey!

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: You tink, becauſe I ſtranger, I not underſtand. Oh, language of love is de ſame in my country, your country, all country. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Hey! What! No, it can't be. Let me think—Um! Faith, it begins to dawn—now it glares! Oh what a blind dolt have I been! Ha! ha! Huzza, I hear myſelf laugh again, and think I could cut a caper—Tol lol de rol! Whew! A fine girl loves me, and ſo. Fortune, go hang.

div.stage: Scene changes to another Apartment in Viſorly's houſe.
Enter LEONARD with a letter in his hand, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Is my father at home?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Tell him I wiſh to ſee him directly [Exit Servant.] (reads.) Sir, knowing you to have the management of Mr. Cleveland's concerns, I write to inform you that the ſhip in which he came paſſenger from India, was wrecked off Portland the 29th ult. and every ſoul periſhed.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Well, my dear boy, what news—what news?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Very important, ſir, Cleveland is no more.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Dear me—dear me!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: By this I learn that the veſſel that brought him from Bengal is wrecked, and he has periſhed.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Poor man! poor man! alack! he was a good twenty years younger than I am—only to think that I ſhould outlive him! Ah, there is no knowing who is to go to the grave firſt—mayhap I may outlive you, Leonard. (weeping.)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, don't indulge ſuch melancholy ideas. His death, tho' to be ſure very dreadful, and likely to awaken ſenſibility in the breaſts of his relations, yet carries with it to us a kind of conſolation.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: How do you mean, Leonard?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
You know my wiſh to be united to his
daughter;—and, perhaps, he might have had in his mind a different alliance for her.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Now my attainment of that object is infinitely more ſecure, the mother and the girl being both under our own roof, and likely now to continue ſo.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Very true. Lord, what a blockhead was I, to fall a blubbering, and for a man too, who, tho' he was my firſt couſin, I ſhould not have known from Adam. But I have a very tender heart.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.p: Yes, and a very ſoft head. (aſide.) But, now, ſir, to break theſe diſmal tidings to his wife and daughter—that muſt be my mother's buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Yes, we will go and prepare her to make the melancholy diſcovery. You have the way, my dear Leonard, of placing things in a right point of view. It is really quite a weakneſs my being ſo tender hearted. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: My dear, dear Julia, what happineſs has heaven allotted me, to compenſate for my paſt wretchedneſs! To have my lovely child reſtored to me, adorned with every grace, endowed with each perfection a mother's fondeſt wiſhes could deſire—Oh, none but a mother can know the happineſs I feel.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: May increaſing joy be ever my dear mother's portion—it muſt—goodneſs like her's muſt be the object of heaven's choiceſt bleſſings.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p:
When your dear father, and the happy youth to whom my Julia has aſſigned her
heart have paſſed the perils of the ocean, and tread ſecure on Engliſh ground, then ſhall I have no wiſh on earth ungratified; but till thoſe joyful tidings reach me, my heart will beat with apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay, do not be alarmed with needleſs terrors. I feel confident of their ſafety.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Ah, my dear girl, yours is the age of ſweet deluſion, when Hope, as yet unknown for a deceiver, promiſes each wiſh acquaintance with reality.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have eſcaped the perils which you dread, and reached your arms in ſafety. Why not be confident the ſame good fate attends on them?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Ah, my Julia—but winds and waves are treacherous—beſides the Foe—nay, that's a ſilly terror—The Ocean is our own, and our extended Fleets, rich with the commerce of the world, fail as ſecurely to their native Ports, as if peace univerſal reigned.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then, free from apprehenſion let us await the ſpeedy completion of our happineſs.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! Oh, my young lady! Oh me, unhappy me!

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Oh, I can't ſpeak—I can't tell you what I know cut your dear hearts, and make dem bleed as mine do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Speak, Child, for heaven's ſake!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Tell us, Gangica, tell us all.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: You will know—you muſt know—but ſpare poor Gangica—don't bid her tell you, for ſear you hate her for making you ſo wretched.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Speak, Gangica, directly.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Your dear, dear father dead—dead—dead.
sp.stage: [Mrs. Cleveland transfixed with horror, Julia ſinks on the ſopha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: (recovering) Where is my child?
Oh, Julia! Julia!
sp.stage: [Burſts into tears, and takes Julia in her arms, Gangica goes to the ſopha, and leans over Julia.

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: I find the diſmal tidings are already known, madam, be comforted.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Alas!—

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: This be a woeful day—alack, alack, that ever I lived to ſee it!

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: A letter has been juſt now brought, directed for Miſs Cleveland (ſhewing the letter) It may contain ſomething important, and I hope—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Pray, give it me—I graſp at any hope—Julia, 'tis from Henry Melville (reads) Snatched by Providence from a wat'ry grave, I haſte to acquaint my deareſt Julia with my ſafety—As my ſituation was infinitely more perilous than her dear father's, I rely on his deliverance, and conclude he will have embraced his lovely daughter before this reaches her. No, no, he has not embraced his lovely daughter—he never will embrace her—

sp.speaker: Lady Jem.
sp.p: Take comfort, madam. You have now ſtrong reaſon to hope the beſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes, deareſt mother, be aſſured the ſame protecting angel has preſerved my father too.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Do, do hope it. Heaven will not forſake the good.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Come, my child—In Heaven I truſt.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Mrs. CLEVELAND, JULIA, and Lady JEMIMA.
[Gangica oppreſſed with grief, remains leaning on the ſopha.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Oh dear, Oh dear, Oh dear! This world be full of troubles. But a little bit ago we were ſo happy as nothing was ever like it—And now it is all weeping and miſery. Oh thoſe devildom hard blowing gales and curſed craggy rocks, they have brought cruel ſorrow to many a family. Poor little Gangica, ſhe takes on as diſmally as any on us. It is a tender-hearted little creature. Gangica, come, dear, don't you droop, you may ſee your young lady's father again, alive and well.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: No, no, no—I never ſee him more—He be ſunk down—deep down—roaring waves roll over him—I never ſee him more.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Yes, yes; heaven will let him live to comfort his wife, his child, ay, and to reward your •• delity.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p:
Oh, if he live—if I ſee him again▪
〈◊〉 be my reward.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Sir, how do you do? Ah, my little dear▪ you here. Why, you have been crying, and you look gloomy too, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; we have neither much cauſe to look chearfully.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I am ſorry for that—I heard indeed that • ll news had arrived which concerns the ladies.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Then, when you know that we belong to thoſe ladies, you can't expect us to be gay when thoſe we love are in affliction.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Very true, ſir. But, poor thing (to Gangica) come, do chear up a little—don't be ſo very diſmal,—do let me ſee you ſmile again.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Smile when I full of ſorrow—Why, you wiſh my face mock my heart.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Come, ſir, leave her as nature made her—don't teach her any of your damn'd faſhionable tricks, making the face look one thing while the heart means another. Go, my good girl, and comfort yourſelf with the hope that we may ſoon have reaſon to ſmile again. [Exit GANGICA. There is a creature that will make me expect in future to find the faireſt mind in a dark coloured caſe. I hope I may live to ſee her as happy as ſhe deſerves to be. If I had but a ſon of my own—but what ſignifies wiſhing?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Ah, what indeed! for have you not a ſon of your own, ſir?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: If I have; I love her too well to wiſh ſhe had him. No, no,—if I had a ſon ſuch as I could wiſh—

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I am afraid you are very hard to pleaſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: I ſhould take great pains to get him this girl for a wife.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: And I am ſo much of your way of thinking, that if you were my father, I ſhould be highly grateful for your kind endeavours.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Would you? then only let me find out that you are worthy of her, and tho' you are a ſtranger to me, I'll do all I can for you (going.)

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: That is very kind of you indeed, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: But, hold, hold;—are you ſure your father would approve of it?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Quite ſure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: He has already ſignified his approbation.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Indeed! When?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Juſt now, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Why, has he ever ſeen the girl?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh Lord, yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Well, well! but I ſhould like to have a little converſation with the old gentleman.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Ah, ſir, you have had a great deal in your time.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: What then I know him.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Nobody half ſo well, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Really! What, an old acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: A very old one, ſir—you knew him long before I did.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul! and pray, ſir, what is your name?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I am called Sharpſet, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Then you muſt be miſtaken, ſir—I have no acquaintance of that name.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: My dear ſir, that is not the family name, that is not my father's name.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Well, what is your father's name?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: The very reaſon, ſir, which made me adopt another name ſtill prevents me from juſt at preſent avowing my real one; but, depend upon it you ſhall know, ſir.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Well, ſir, whenever it is proper to tell me, I ſhall be glad to know, (going) but give me your hand for your father's ſake.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: And I graſp yours with affection—for my father's ſake. [Exeunt ſeverally▪

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That, I find, is the houſe of Mr. Viſorly. There I ſhall learn my Julia's reſidence. This is but a ſorry garb for a lover to ſeek his miſtreſs in; but if I know my Julia's heart, her joy at finding me preſerved from death, will make her little heed, or ſcarcely ſee the poorneſs of my raiment. Her father's ſafety, though I little doubt it, I long to be aſſured of. Now then, to be reſolved on that important point, and meet my Julia.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: To find ſhe is in this houſe is more good fortune than I could hope.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Henry! To behold you again after ſuch danger—But where is my father?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Have you not ſeen him yet?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, no, no—tell me, does he live?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I hope ſo, Julia.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, is it only hope?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
