Be comforted—he may be ſafe, he ſurely muſt. Soon as our veſſel bulged on the rock, and the impetuous torrent ruſhed at the dreadful chaſm to o'erwhelm us, the boats were inſtantly hauled
out, and in a moment throng'd. In one, leaſt crowded, was your father; he called to me, and earneſtly conjured me to come into it—As I was going to comply, I ſaw a poor old man kneeling to heaven to ſave him from the fate his feeble age denied him to contend againſt. The boat could ſafely hold but one—I placed him in it, ſeized on a friendly coop, and with it truſted to the waves.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My generous Henry! But my father—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: The ſea was very boiſterous, and often waſhed over me; yet, at intervals I ſnatched a ſhort view, and ſtill ſaw his boat riding in ſafety. At length the burſting billows ſhowering ſo frequently their torrents on me, deluged my ſenſes. When I recovered them, I found myſelf in a ſmall veſſel, whoſe crew had humanely reſcued me from death.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh my poor father!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Nay, droop not, Julia—This veſſel was a ſloop of war ſailing for the Downs. Before I recovered, it was under weigh, I was therefore forced to remain in it till it gain'd its ſtation.—Landed at Deal, I could of courſe hear no tidings of your father, whoſe boat, no doubt, ſafely reached the neareſt ſhore. His not being yet arrived, argues nothing againſt his ſafety.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But, would he not have written to acquaint us with it?—News of the wreck could reach us, but no intelligence from him—No, he is gone! My father is gone for ever.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: My Julia's grief diſtracts me—Still let me hope 'tis without cauſe; but as no moment ſhould be loſt to prove it groundleſs, I will this inſtant fly to know the truth▪ Farewell, my Julia! When next we meet, I truſt all grief will vaniſh.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Where have you been? I never wanted your aſſiſtance more, and I have been hunting after you of late in vain.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Whew! you ſeem in a bleſſed humour. What has produced ſuch an amiable tone of temper?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: All my ſcheme is likely to be ruined. There is a lover, a favoured lover, come to light.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh the deuce!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes, ſaved from the wreck—damnation! But there is ſtill one conſolation, he brings no tidings of the father. The waves have not ſpared him.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Poor man!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Amiable tenderneſs!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Mock as you will, I cannot, like you, ſteel my heart againſt the common feelings of humanity.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Pſha! he's dead—Will your preaching reanimate him? No. Then to the purpoſe of doing ſervice to the living, of aiding your friend.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: This girl, now the rightful inheritor of her father's immenſe fortune, muſt be mine.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: But you tell me of a lover.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes, and there is not time for endeavouring to undermine his hold on her heart—Meaſures muſt be adopted, ſudden and forcible.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: To bear her away. Once in my poſſeſſion, all may go ſmoothly: at her age, nay, at any age, a transfer of affection is no uncommon incident.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: But the difficulty—See how ſhe is ſurrounded.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Difficulty! every difficulty yields to the enterpriſing. Her lover is gone, like a true hero of romance, to conjure up the dead. 'Tis eaſy to get the reſt out of the way—Firſt, I'll remove the main obſtacle, her ruſtic protector.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Remove him! how do you mean, remove him?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We muſt lack invention, indeed, not to effect that—By an hundred ſtratagems we can keep him out of the way long enough to anſwer my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: But I have a trifling objection to his being put to the ſlighteſt inconvenience.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Objection? what?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: He only happens to be my father.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What do you ſay? your father?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me. Well, well, this may turn to account. Then you may have influence to bring him over to my intereſt.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Not I, nor all the world would be able to influence him to a diſhoneſt action—Beſide, friend Leonard, to let you into a ſecret, I neither like your ſcheme, nor wiſh to forward it. After a long abſence, I have had the happineſs to meet my father, and when I behold in him what a glow of youth an honeſt heart infuſes into an aged face, I am determined to abandon my roguery, and try to make the roſy honours of honeſty, hereditary.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You mean, then, to defeat my purpoſes?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I certainly mean not to aid them.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But am I to expect your oppoſition?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I hope, Leonard, your own reflections will render that needleſs. Could you have fairly gained the girl's affections, I ſhould have rejoiced at your ſucceſs, and thought the ſociety of an amiable woman the likelieſt ſchool for forming an honeſt man; but force—to uſe force againſt a lovely, helpleſs female, none but a devil could inſpire the thought, and none but devils could be found to execute it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Bravo! one might judge by your energy that you were a new-made proſelyte. Apoſtates are always the maddeſt enthuſiaſts—But, fool! do you think I am to be preached out of my intentions?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: And do you think I am to be bullied out of mine?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, ſir, take your courſe, but be cautious that you do not thwart me—Dare not to breathe a word of my deſigns, unleſs your devotion to your new tenets is warm enough to make you welcome a priſon in their defence. Mark me, a priſon. You may remember there are certain bonds of yours in my poſſeſſion that give me as entire a power over your perſon, as tho' you were my purchaſed ſlave. Remember this, and act accordingly. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: How my blood boils at the villain! too true he has me in his power; but I'll keep him in view—I'll watch his motions. I've deſerved a priſon before now, and have eſcaped it; well, then, if I am brought to one at laſt for a good deed, all's ſquare again, and I begin the world a freſh man.

div.stage: Enter DROOPLY, repeating as he enters.

q.l: Come, thou goddeſs, fair and free,

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Why, Drooply—ſurpriſing! ſo ſprightly—ſo gay!

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Gay as a lark, my boy.

q.l: Haſte thee, nymph, and bring with thee

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: What, have you found your eſtate again?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: No; but I have found myſelf again. I've regained my ſpirits, and they are worth all the eſtates in the univerſe.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: But what has effected this wonderful change?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What! need you aſk? what can breathe animation into a clod of deſpondency, but woman, dear, lovely, angelic woman.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: So, you have gained your ſpirits by loſing your heart.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes; and a man hardly knows he has a heart till he loſes it. But, huzza! I am in love, and what is more, I am beloved—Damn my eſtate, and give me your hand, my boy, though you won it.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I won it! yes, and won it fairly too.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Who doubts it? not I, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Why then may be you ought.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: You are a comical dog.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: I ſay perhaps you ought to doubt it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Heyday—the oddeſt kind of quizzing this! the man who won my eſtate, wanting to make me believe I was cheated of it. You are a deviliſh droll dog! but I have ſomething elſe to do than to mind your waggery▪ (going.)

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Stay! you are an honeſt fellow, and have been damn'd unlucky in your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Poh, poh, poh!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Drooply, when a man aſſures you of his honeſty, I'll give you leave to doubt him; but when he inſiſts on his knavery, don't be ſo ſtupidly incredulous.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What are you driving at?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Plainly to tell you, you have been duped, cheated—robbed.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: By you?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Yes;—but I have been only ſecond in command. Do you remember by whoſe kindneſs you were firſt made happy with my acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Hum! yes; by my friend, Leonard Viſorly.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: He is my commanding officer.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Leonard! my friend! my patron!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Your plunderer—He laid plans which I only executed—he received the booty while I was paid but a ſubaltern's ſhare.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I am petrified.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: But be ſilent—be prudent! for I've but ſhewn you your malady, without being able to preſcribe a remedy. He has played the politician ſo well, that his villainy is known only to me—the minor agents were all of my employing—So, remember, don't break out; for you have nothing but my teſtimony to ſupport an accuſation, and he has wound his ſnares ſo well, that he has me in his toils. Adieu! be cautious, and truſt that the day of retribution will come. [Exit SHARPSET.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p:
Here is a damper to my gaiety! not even love can ſupport a man's ſpirits againſt ingratitude. I loſt my fortune; but ſtill I thought I had a friend left. To find that friend my—Oh damn it, I can't bear the thought. I'll go inſtantly
and ſeek Caroline; but how to tell her of her brother's villainy? I hope I may not meet him—I ſhou'd not know how to—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Drooply! (holding out his hand).

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: How do you do? How do you do?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What, wont you ſhake hands with me?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Won't I ſhake hands with you! that is a good joke (holding out his hand, and then drawing it back). Not but I think ſhaking hands a curſed fooliſh habit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Becauſe in this damn'd hypocritical world one often gives the gripe of friendſhip to a ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Very true; one is often miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes, miſerably.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But when we come to the knowledge of a friend's real worth—

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: It ſometimes teaches us to conſider him a friend no longer.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Your gloom, I find, has taken the general courſe, and led you to miſanthropy. When men have been unfortunate they generally grow unjuſt.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes; and for that there is ſome excuſe—But when men are unjuſt and fortunate too, what black ſouls they muſt have.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Very true; but have you had experience of ſuch?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Havn't I loſt a fortune?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes—by play, not knavery.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Why, play and knavery are ſo much connected, that I can't ſeparate them for the ſoul of me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You appear to have ſuſpicions.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: No, no ſuſpicions at all.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You ſurely talk as if you had doubts.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: You miſtake—I have not a doubt on the ſubject. Good bye! I am very miſerable, and of courſe very bad company for you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: When we meet again I ſhall be glad to ſee you more chearful.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Why, when we meet again, Leonard—Farewel. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Um! all is not as it ſhould be! Can that villain, Sharpſet, have dared reveal to him—I fear it—and if he have betrayed me to him, he will not ſtop there. His malice then, muſt have a check—he ſhall inſtantly be taken care of. I have the power to ſecure him. The old ruſtic, whom he calls his father, I have been forced to entrap ſomewhat illegally; but he will be ſafe till my ſcheme is executed, and then the fellow that I have bribed to ſwear a debt againſt him, may, by flight, ſecure himſelf from the vengeance of the violated law. All is well arranged, and this very night ſhall put me ſecurely in poſſeſſion of my Eaſtern beauty, and her Eaſtern riches. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: But what right, I ſay, have you to keep me here againſt my will?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Lord love your heart, I don't vant to keep any Gemman in my houſe againſt his vill.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Then let me out directly.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: You may go farther, and fare vorſe. Vhere do do you think to go?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Why, home to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: That is a deviliſh good one. You are a comical kind of a Gemman; but a great many comical Gemmen wiſits me—I ſees moſt of the vits one time or other.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Have done with your nonſenſe, and let me go home—And dam'me but I'll trounce you and the raſcals who brought me here.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Vy, as for your trouncing, I laughs at that. I does nothing but vat I can juſtify.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: What! can you juſtify kidnapping a man in the ſtreets? I am too old to go for a ſoldier. If I were not, and my country wanted me, I ſhould not need be dragged to my duty.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Vat do you talk about kidnapping for? You knows as vell as I can tell you vy you came here.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: I'll be curſed if I do.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Vy, you know if you paid your debts, you could not be brought into trouble.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Pay my debts! I don't owe a farthing to mortal man.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Come, come, do behave a little genteelly. There is nothing unlike a Gemman in not paying your debts; but it's damn'd ſhabby to deny 'em.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Well, ſir, ſince you inſiſt upon it, pray, whom may I be indebted to?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: (looking at the writ). "To Thomas Teſtify von hundred pounds."

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: I never heard of ſuch a man—I am not the perſon. It is a miſtake.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.q: Come, come, old one, that's too bad.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.q: I tell you it is all a miſtake—Let me out, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.q: Yes, yes; to take you to Newgate, if you like.'— (Noiſe without).

sp.speaker: SHARPSET
sp.p: Ay, ay, it is all right. I owe the money—That can't be denied.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.q: Only mind this honeſt Gemman, he doesn't pretend to humbug people as you do.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: What! (ſeeing Oakworth). You here, ſir!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Oh, they know von another—Both of a kidney, I varrant. Oh, that old one is a deep one. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: How came you here, ſir!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Dragged here—dragged by main force.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: On what pretence?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Becauſe they want to perſuade me I owe a hundred pounds to a Mr. Thomas Teſtify.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Whom you know nothing of?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: No more than the man in the moon.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Sir, there is rank villainy going forward.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Yes, that is pretty clear.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: You muſt ſend directly for Mrs. Cleveland—Every thing dear to herſelf depends on it. Therefore ſend to her immediately, and tell her not to leave her daughter—

sp.speaker: Mrs. CLEVELAND
sp.p: Let me ſee him inſtantly; and, Gangica, do you ſtay under the care of the ſervants. My good friend, do I find you in a place like this?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: And are you ſo very good as to ſeek me in a place like this? How came you to know of my being here?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: You ſent for me, did you not?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p:
Amazing! A meſſenger came to me, acquainting me with your ſituation, and directing
me where to find you—On which you may conclude I loſt no time in haſtening to you.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Dear, good creature!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: But who can have been ſo kind to inform me where?—

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: The kindneſs, madam, was the kindneſs of the devil, who often puts on the ſemblance of goodneſs only to betray. Quit this place, and return home inſtantly—There is a villainous deſign againſt your daughter—Your abſence and his, has been artfully cauſed, to effect her ruin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Oh, horrible!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Loſe not a moment in queſtioning, or all is loſt—Though the debt alledged, be a falſe one, give your draft for it, and take him with you. Haſte, madam, haſte; and heaven proſper you.

div.stage: SCENE—The Garden belonging to Old VISORLY'S Houſe.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: The evening is as dark as I cou'd wiſh. The moon has civilly withdrawn her intruſive rays. The mother and Oakworth are admirably diſpoſed of. My own family too conveniently from home; for, though I am not ſure they would thwart a deſign ſo greatly for my advantage, yet, I had rather be without needleſs confidants. Simpſon! Simpſon!

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Is the carriage at the garden gate, and every thing in readineſs?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Yes, ſir▪

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Very well. Wait hereabout, or be at the garden gate. [Exit SIMPSON.
Now, then, to my young lady. [Exit.

div.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment in VISORLY'S Houſe.
div.p: I wiſh my mother would return, and bring me news of poor Oakworth. 'Tis hard, that he, ſo good and friendly to others, ſhould himſelf experience cruel treatment. Alas! my ſpirits quite ſink under the preſſure of misfortune. Oh, my dear father, may I hope ever again to be bleſſed with thy fond embrace?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Ha! who is there? (finding it to be Leonard). I beg your pardon, ſir, for my childiſh alarm. But I am really ſo weak, that I am agitated by the ſlighteſt circumſtance. Indeed I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Madam, my ſituation is a moſt unfortunate one. I hoped by years of attention to your every wiſh, to have convinced you, that for you alone I cheriſhed exiſtence.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But I have the miſery to find your hand is not unpromiſed, nor, I fear, your mind uninfluenced.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sir, my hand and heart are both moſt ſolemnly affianced.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Then all my cheriſhed hopes are vaniſhed. I thought to have convinced you by every action, that my ſoul was your's before my lips ſhould
venture the confeſſion. I indulged the gay dream, that by my tender aſſiduity you might be won to ſympathy, and have heard me breathe the vows of love with looks that ſpoke a language—Ah! how remote from what they now convey—Yet even thoſe looks, ſo adverſe to my wiſhes—thoſe eyes, could they dart death, ſhould not impede me from declaring this heart to you devoted, never will forego its claim.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sir! what mean you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Liſted under Love's banner, never to deſert his cauſe. You muſt—You ſhall be mine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Horrible!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: A whole life of tenderneſs ſhall atone for what has now the look of violence (approaches her).

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Violence! Oh, heaven! help! help! Oh! (ſhe faints, he catches her in his arms).

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: She is mine! [Exit, bearing her off.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well, I have found no great difficulty in ſcampering over the garden wall—If any of the family ſhould find me here though, I ſhould be ſtrangely ſuſpected of either an intrigue or a burglary—It was an excellent thought of Caroline's to let me know when we ſhould next meet, by leaving a letter for me in a ſly corner of the pavilion; for, there is no truſting ſervants—I'll e'en get my dear little packet, and over the wall again (going towards the Pavilion). Ha! I hear ſomebody coming (in his hurry to get to the Pavilion, he ſ • umbles over a garden chair.)

div.stage: Enter LEONARD, with JULIA in his arms.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, you are there, Simpſon! here, take the lady in your arms. A fortunate fainting fit has prevented outcry. Place her in the carriage, while I return for an inſtant, for I have forgot to provide myſelf with the moſt material companion for long journies. Here, take one of my piſtols, and defend your prize at the hazard of your life.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What the devil ſhall I do? And what prize have I got here?
sp.stage: [The moon burſting by degrees from a cloud.
sp.p: My ſweet, pretty moon, do enlighten me a little more, that I may ſee who I am hugging ſo lovingly (it grows lighter). Thank you kindly, my dear Lady Luna. What, the young Eaſt Indian! Oh, that villain!—She revives! Don't be alarm'd, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Where am I? Who are you?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: No agent of villainy; but one who will protect you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh, where is that wretch; am I in his power?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: No, madam, nor ever ſhall be. Ha! he is coming.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Let me fly from his ſight.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: There, madam, into that Pavilion.
sp.stage: [He goes with her, enters it, and brings out Caroline's letter in his hand.
sp.p: She is ſafe, and I have got my dear Caroline's letter—So, now, Mr. Leonard, have at you!
sp.stage: [Leonard enters, and is croſſing the ſtage; Drooply meets him—Drooply has put the piſtol in his pocket.

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Drooply! What do you do here?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I am only engaged in a little affair of gallantry.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What here! Do you diſgrace my father's houſe with your gallantries?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Do you never diſgrace your father's houſe with your gallantries?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Inſolent!

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: No, no; I muſt do you the juſtice to own, you carry your gallantries out of your father's houſe.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Mean! Sure you forget Simpſon is in the ſecret.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What of Simpſon?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: An't I Simpſon? You did me the honour to ſalute me ſo juſt now.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Damnation! Well, ſir, then there is your charge?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Here, you villain (preſents his piſtol).

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Drooply, I am in your power—command any thing—do but this inſtant reſtore me Julia, and you ſhall again glitter in gaiety, again be the rich, the courted Drooply.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes, to be pillaged again, you conclude, by the well-laid ſchemes of the friendly Mr. Viſorly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.q: Yes, I know your baſeneſs—This heart, which once felt only gratitude and friendſhip towards you, now deſpiſes and abhors you—This tongue, once laviſh in your praiſe, and prodigal of thanks, now execrates your infamy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
This is no time to prove my innocence. I am traduced, vilely ſlandered—All this I can
up, and will; but the moments are moſt precious to me. Where is the lady? reſtore me Julia, and make your own terms.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What terms do you think wou'd bribe me to reſtore a lovely innocent to a villain's power? I am poor, I am wretchedly poor. But, would you return my fortune, would you add your own, your father's, nay, all the wealth of this rich city, it ſhould not bribe me to an act of villainy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Be prudent, and attend to what I ſay.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I'll attend to one thing you ſaid moſt ſtrictly. You charged me to defend my prize at the hazard of my life—That I do moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Drooply, urge me no further—I am deſperate—Julia muſt be mine—Be wiſe, accept the offers of my friendſhip—don't riſk my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Your vengeance! poh! what! becauſe you found me gentle, nay, humble, to the man I thought my friend and patron, do you think I want ſpirit to oppoſe a robber and a raviſher? Leonard, be aſſured it is a vaſt pleaſure to me to have a pop at you on my own account; but had I no wrongs, ſooner than be your accomplice in the ruin of an unprotected woman, dam'me, but I would march up to you if you held a lighted match to the touch-hole of a nine-pounder. (g • e • up cloſe to him.)

sp.speaker: OAKWORTH
sp.p: She muſt have been taken this way.

div.stage: Enter OAKWORTH, Mrs. CLEVELAND and GANGICA. The moment OAKWORTH ſees LEONARD and DROOPLY he runs down the ſtage and collars them both.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Give her up, give her up this inſtant, or I'll throttle you both.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Where is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Ay, where is the lady? give her up directly—Curſe your piſtols, I don't mind your piſtols—Give her up, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: (to LEONARD.) Heavens! is it you? you concerned in this villainy? where is my daughter, ſir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Aſk that gentleman—He has conveyed her hence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: You, then, that I have accuſed, are her defender, I aſk your pardon.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: May I periſh if he isn't making his bow for the mother's civility.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Where is my daughter, ſir? (to DROOPLY.)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: There is one hope left. If he conveyed her to the carriage (and where elſe could he) they have doubtleſs driven off with her. Where is the lady, villain?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Dam'me, if his impudence does not petrify me.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: (ruſhing up to him.) Ay, where is the lady, villain?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: A little patience, you ſhall know the whole.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No, ſir, no fabrications, no fictions—Where is the lady?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Should you be pleaſed to ſee her?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Doubtleſs.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Oh, I'll do any thing to oblige you. (goes to the pavilion and leads her out.) Now, ſir, why don't you appeal to the lady to proclaim your innocence? what, dumb! ah, I know your modeſty of old. Then I will ſpeak for you. From which of us, madam, have you experienced this outrage?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Oh, from him, from him. (pointing to LEONARD.)
Mrs. CLEVELAND and OAKWORTH expreſs aſtoniſhment, and LEONARD ruſhes out.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: That is right, Leonard—move off; but run as faſt as you will, the devil muſt overtake you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Then to you I owe my daughter's preſervation. Oh, ſir, accept a mother's thanks.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Offer them, madam, to Providence only, which made me the humble inſtrument to preſerve an angel, and expoſe a fiend. Where, madam, ſhall I have the honour of conducting you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Any where ſo I avoid that hated habitation.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Let us go, madam, to the hotel where we firſt arrived.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: And where, would to heaven, we had remained. Come, deareſt Julia. [Exeunt.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Oh, Leonard, Leonard, it is a bad buſineſs, a very bad buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: So is every thing unſucceſsful, ſir. Were I now in poſſeſſion of the girl and her fortune, you might probably not be condemning the means by which I accompliſhed it.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhould—I ſhould condemn ſuch means. Oh fie! againſt her will.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Seemingly, ſir, only ſeemingly—The man who would deal ſucceſsfully with the ſex muſt often force them to follow their own inclinations.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: I don't know that; but I have found that the man who would deal quietly with the ſe • is always forced to let them follow their own inclinations.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: It was a deſperate effort; but the only chance left for obtaining her. That foiled, ſhe is loſt moſt certainly, perhaps her fortune too.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Perhaps! why, to be ſure it is. If ſhe is loſt, her fortune muſt be loſt—You can't contrive to marry the fortune without marrying the girl, can you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No, ſir: but with your aid the fortune may be ours without the incumbrance.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: The fortune ours—Eh, how?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Had Cleveland died unmarried you were his heir.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Yes—what of that?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Are we ſure he did not die unmarried?

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: We ſhould be pretty ſure, I think, when he has left a wife and child behind to convince us.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Is ſhe his wife? Can ſhe prove herſelf ſuch?

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: By his own account the marriage was a private one, a private marriage in the Eaſt-Indies! Reflect firſt on the probability of its being no marriage, and next conſider the difficulty of proving it, if it were one.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Yes, yes, very true. But you ſurely do not doubt the marriage therefore to claim a property, becauſe, perhaps, legal proof can't be obtained—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Is, you think, not ſtrictly within the pale of moral rectitude.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: I can't ſay but I am of that opinion.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, deſpiſe all abſtract refinement, and be aſſured that you fulfil every moral obligation when your conduct is ſanctioned by the laws of your country.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: There is ſomething in that; but yet juſtice, you know, can only be guided by appearances, and one's conſcience will not always acquieſce—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: My dear ſir, when your conſcience oppoſes a legal decree, you ſhould conſider it as acting contumaciouſly, and that it ought to be ſilenced for contempt of the court.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: If I could be ſatisfied that they were really not married.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
There is ſtrong preſumption. Would Cleveland's father, think you, have endeavoured to diſſolve the ſacred ties of marriage? Have inſiſted
on his ſon's abruptly diſmiſſing—a wife? No, no, ſir—depend on it, the father, anxious for his ſon's reſpectability, demanded only his parting with a favourite miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Very likely—very likely—I always ſaid you had the way of placing things in a right point of view, Oh, my ſcruples are gone—ſhould I be robbed of my right by a miſtreſs, and a—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Certainly not, ſir. Now then you are convinced of the rectitude of your cauſe, let me urge a ſtrong motive for proceeding with vigour. I have this morning received the unwelcome tidings of the failure of a ſpeculation in which I had embarked the entire amount of my own fortune, ſo that I am now compelled to become a burthen to you.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: O lord, lord, dear me, how ſorry I am to hear it; for, my dear boy, to let you into the true ſtate of my affairs—Lady Jemima's curſed faſhionable ſtile of living has made ſuch a miſerable hole in my property, that it is not clear to me, but I may die in a jail.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You amaze me, ſir—then, this is our only reſource, and at all hazards we muſt accompliſh it.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Oakworth deſires to ſee both you and my young maſter directly, ſir.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Very well. [Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I'll keep out of his way. He is a paſſionate old fellow, and I am ſure he would loſe his temper with me. Do you ſee him, ſir, and let him • e the bearer of your determination.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: How is my dear child now?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Better, much better, thanks to your tender care.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Oh the wretch that could alarm my angel thus, and aim by violence to tear my precious treaſure from her mother's arms! Heaven's vengeance will await him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My ſpirits would, I think, ſoon recover this rude ſhock, but for the dread that overpowers me for the fate of my dear father.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Ah, my child, I fear— (ſeeing JULIA much depreſſed.) Yet, ſtill, my love, there is hope, that hope we will cheriſh. Come, my child, take comfort—take comfort, deareſt Julia.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh, what are all the riches we poſſeſs without my father!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Poor indeed! but we will truſt he yet ſurvives to beſtow a value on the gifts of fortune.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Oh Lord, Oh Lord, what will this world come too?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Roguery! Villainy! Infamy!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Where? from what quarter?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: From the devil's neſt, the houſe of the Viſorlys.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Pray, let me know the worſt.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: I will—I will—As you deſired me, I demanded that all the property remitted by Mr. Cleveland ſhould be conſigned to you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Well, could they refuſe it?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: They did—they did—I mean the old one did; for the young raſcal took care to keep out of my way. He was wiſe—he was wiſe there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: But on what plea, on what pretence were you refuſed?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: A wicked pretence, a damnable pretence—a pretence they ought to ſwing for.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: What—what?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: That they did not believe—they did not believe—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Muſt I tell you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Yes, pray do.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: That you were—Mr. Cleveland's wife—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Gracious heaven!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Yes; and he ſaid that he was heir at law, and ſhould not part with a ſixpence of what was his right.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Oh, Julia!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Dear mother, can this man's prepoſterous claim give you a moment's concern?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: My child, we are loſt—We are ruined.

sp.speaker: Oakw
sp.p: What do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Never till this moment did I reflect that I have no legal teſtimony in my poſſeſſion to prove myſelf a wife. Married in India, in private too—my huſband dead—my child without a proof of—Oh God, Oh God!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Compoſe yourſelf, dear madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Hard as my lot is, were I alone concerned I might feel reſignation; but my dear girl, my lovely Julia—heireſs of thouſands, is—the child of poverty.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Dear mother, do not let me add to your
affliction—With you, with ſuch a mother I can bear poverty, I can indeed.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Poverty—no, no, not ſo bad as poverty.—You know I have a home—'tis but an humble one to be ſure, and I am a tough old fellow, I can work like a horſe.—Poverty, not ſo bad as poverty either.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh Henry!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Julia—deareſt Julia, you are in tears, and you have cauſe—I hoped to dry them, but, alas—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Then my dear huſband is no more.
sp.stage: [HENRY holds down his head deſpondently, aſſenting in ſilence.
sp.p: My cup of miſery is full, (after a pauſe) ſir, you were to have been united to my daughter, her father ſanctioned your affections: I am informed he loved your merits, and thought them, tho' uncombined with fortune, ſufficient to entitle you to the heireſs of his wealth. I now muſt tell you that wealth is loſt to her.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: For her ſake I lament it, not for my own.—To her generous father's bounty I owe almoſt exiſtence,—he found me only grateful, and his goodneſs called mere gratitude deſert; for I fear I have no merit, but an honeſt heart—yet, while that ſhall beat within my breaſt, I'll preſs my Julia to it, nor would I reſign my dear, my deſtined bride to be the huſband of an Empreſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Oh, little do the vicious know how precious are the ſweets of virtue! that alone can elevate the ſoul amidſt calamity and poverty.

div.stage: [The Maſter of the Hotel enters as ſhe is finiſhing the laſt ſpeech.]

sp.speaker: Maſ. of Hot.
sp.p: (To OAKWORTH, as he is going out.) Sir, ſir, a word with you, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: Maſ. of Hot.
sp.p: This hotel of mine, ſir, ſtands at a very great rent.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: So I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Maſ. of Hot.
sp.p: Taxes come very high.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Maſ. of Hot.
sp.p: A great many ſervants.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: So I ſee—and what the devil is all this to me?

sp.speaker: Maſ. of Hot.
sp.p: It ought to make people conſider.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Don't plague me about what people ought to conſider.

sp.speaker: Maſ. of Hot.
sp.p: To cut the matter ſhort, ſir, you know that one of the ladies, as I came into the room, was owning her poverty.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Eh! what?

sp.speaker: Maſ. of Hot.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; and as I can't afford to loſe my money, I beg leave to hint that I ſhall look to you to ſee my bill fairly diſcharged.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Impudent ſcoundrel!

sp.speaker: Maſ. of Hot.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall teach you to uſe better language to a man in his own houſe.

div.stage: Enter a Gentleman, followed by a Waiter.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Heyday, nothing but buſtle and uproar!

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: I hope you are not hurt, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Not at all; but no thanks for that to the careleſs dog of a poſtilion who overturned me. I have been quarrelling with him outſide of the houſe, and I find you are at the ſame employment within. Get me a coach directly. (To the Waiter.)

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, ſir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Well, what is the matter here?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Only this worthy maſter of the houſe inſulting his cuſtomers.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: That is an odd way of recommending himſelf.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: (To Landlord.) Away with you, and be careful that you let none of your inſolence break out before the ladies, or I'll be the death of you, you dog.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir, give me leave to aſk, that is, if there be no offence in the queſtion, are the ladies you mention under any pecuniary embarraſſment? for it would be a ſad thing to have ladies liable to the rudeneſs of this unfeeling fellow.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: No, ſir, thank heaven! Even my poor pocket could ſatisfy his paltry demands. No, no,—tho' they are unfortunate, they are not in the power of ſuch a pitiful ſcoundrel as that.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I am glad of it; but ſtill you ſay they are unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Yes; miſery be the lot of the villians who made them ſo!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Who are thoſe villians.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Their own relations.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Heav'ns, what depravity! But can't this villiany be in any way redreſſed?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Only one way, if at all; and there the remedy would be as bad as the diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: What is the remedy.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Going to law.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: If law can give the remedy, redreſs is certain; in this country the way to juſtice is not through blind mazes and crooked paths—No, 'tis a public road, open to all, obvious to all.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p:
That is very true; but like other public
roads, you would get on a very little way, without money to pay the tolls.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: The warm intereſt you take in the cauſe of your friends convinces me that they are worthy of it. I have a fortune, an ample fortune, and I can no way employ it ſo ſatisfactorily as in reſcuing the virtuous from the machinations of villainy.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Sir, ſir, let me rightly underſtand you. I beg your pardon; but do you indeed mean to employ your fortune to relieve the diſtreſs of ſtrangers, utter ſtrangers to you?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Certainly, or how ſhould I relieve diſtreſs at all; for all that belong to me, thank heaven, are above the power of fortune's malice.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Bleſs you! bleſs you! the widow's bleſſing—the orphan's—

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Nay, nay, good old man, I were bleſt enough for all that I can do, in ſeeing how happy I have made you. But a widow—an orphan, ſay you? Thoſe are ſacred names. The huſband gone, who is protector to the widow!—Heaven—The parent loſt, who is the orphan's father? Heaven. The man then, who will not aſſert their rights, is not uncharitable only; for he is impious.—Good man, why do you tremble thus?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: I am old—I feel now, I am an old man; and tho' my nerves, I think, would bear me ſtoutly up, under adverſity, yet, ſomehow this ſudden turn of good fortune has ſhook me, has ſhook me a good deal.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Compoſe yourſelf—then tell the ladies that I ſhall ſee them very ſoon; for I now muſt go.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Don't go, don't go yet. Let them hear, ſir, from your own lips your goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p:
My buſineſs hence is nothing trivial; and only a caſe of misfortune could have detained me
here an inſtant; therefore aſſure your friends—But why not debar myſelf a few moments longer of my own gratification, to convince them of my certain protection (aſide) my good old friend, tell the ladies I wait to ſee them. [Exit OAKWORTH. Ay, ay, 'twill make but a few minutes difference, and the dear good creatures I ſo long to behold will forgive me when I tell them that the cauſe of my delay, was to dry the tear of affliction.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. CLEVELAND, led in by OAKWORTH, JULIA following with HENRY.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Sir, your goodneſs—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: My wife! my child! Oh, heavenly powers!

div.stage: Enter DROOPLY and CAROLINE, a Waiter following with a Portmanteau, and a ſmall iron box.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Put the things carefully into a chamber, and be ſure take care of that little box.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Yes, ſir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And here we are, my deareſt Caroline, with the parſon's bleſſing upon us. I hardly durſt raiſe my hopes to this happineſs, even before your worthy brother contrived to make me an eſtate out of pocket; but my generous girl, when I reflect that you take a beggar to your arms—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, I am only doing an act of common honeſty, in paying the debts of my family; and I am to conſider you a very gentle creditor
to be ſatisfied with leſs than a third of your demand, and to take charge of me into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: My deareſt girl!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But, amidſt our happineſs, let us not forget the melancholy ſituation of the dear Clevelands—Let us inſtantly try to ſee them.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Here comes the little Gentoo full of glee. Oh, this looks well!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Gangica!

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: Ah, you here! Oh I glad of dat—I ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What has happened to make you ſo.

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: (pointing to her heart.) Dis too full of joy to let me talk. I can't tell you—but come—come wid me—you know all—den you be too happy to talk—Come, come. [Exeunt▪

div.stage: CLEVELAND, Mrs. CLEVELAND, JULIA, and HENRY.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: The villains! ample ſhall be their puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: It will be ample, be aſſured; but do not you wreſt vengeance from that Power who beſt knows how to deal it, that Power which never withholds its ſuccour from the innocent, nor le • s the guilty 'ſcape its awful indignation.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.q: But ſay, my father, by what miracle are you reſtored to us?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.q:
Henry, no doubt, has told you that he ſaw me in the boat, which his humanity declined a place in—We laboured for the neareſt ſhore▪
but ound that an attempt to land would whelm us in the raging ſurf—thus were we compelled to truſt our little ſkiff to the wide ocean, and for many hours were driven at random by its fury—At length we gained the land, but far from the coaſt on which we left our wreck.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But why did you not, the inſtant that you landed, acquaint us with your ſafety?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Alas! I had loſt the power of doing ſo. Enfeebled by fatigue, when I reached the ſhore, I ſcarce had ſenſe or motion, a fever followed, from which reaſon and health returned together—So, on the inſtant I ſet out to be myſelf the herald of my ſafety.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I ſought you on the coaſt near Portland.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Well might you hear no tidings of me; for we made our landing at the Iſle of Wight, to the humanity of whoſe inhabitants myſelf and poor companions owe our lives. Think you thoſe wretches, the Viſorlys will venture to you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Convinced that you are no longer living, I have no doubt but the inſtructions we have given to Oakworth to communicate, will bring them here.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: The young one has never ſeen me, and Old Viſorly not ſince I was quite a child; ſo it is impoſſible I ſhould be known.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: But promiſe to preſerve your temper.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Depend on me.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: (without) This way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: I hear Oakworth's voice. We will retire.

div.stage: Enter OAKWORTH, OLD VISORLY, and LEONARD.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: This is the ſtranger I told you of. I leave you with the gentleman, begging his pardon for introducing him to ſuch damn'd bad company.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We underſtand that you have volunteered to defend the cauſe of Mrs. Cleveland. Are we rightly informed, ſir?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: You are.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I thought the days of chivalry were over.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: So did I: but ſince monſters ſtill exiſt,—'tis fit that they revive again.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You have begun your career of enterprize, moſt illuſtrious knight, with rather a hopeleſs adventure.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: It may not be found ſo.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You ſeem an intelligent man. A little converſation will, I have no doubt, bring us to the ſame opinion, and all errors will be rectified before we part.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: You need not doubt it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Now, my boy, Leonard, will talk him over in a grand ſtile. Oh, he is a bleſſing to my old age. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: This woman has the power of influencing perſons very much in her favour.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Innocence always has that power.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Innocence! Sir, ſir, you are duped, deceived.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.q: How, ſir!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: Nay, ſir, if you fly off in this way, you are not the man of ſenſe I take you for.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.q: Well, ſir, go on.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: You are led to believe this lady to have been Mr. Cleveland's wife.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.q: Yes, ſir; I am—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: Groſsly impoſed on. We have the moſt convincing reaſons to believe the contrary.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.q: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: Sir, ſir, what do you think of us? Should we be ſo loſt to the common feelings of human nature as to proceed as we have done, but upon juſt ground?

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.q: Oh, I aſſure you, ſir, before I conſented, Leonard thoroughly convinced me.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.q: He did?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.q: Yes, and you ſhall be convinced. Oh, ſir, let me appeal to your reſpectability. You are a man who muſt, I am certain, rank high in the world's eſtimation. How would that be injured by your preſent interference! How would the world deſpiſe, abhor the man who could ſupport the claims of mere pretenders againſt a rightful heir!

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.q: How the world will deſpiſe, will abhor ſuch a wretch, will very ſoon be known.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You, perhaps, are not aware that ſhe has no proofs of her marriage.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Proofs may be found.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: In India, you think. Will you go thither for them?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I have been.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I have been.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You knew Cleveland, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Do you know, then, of his marriage?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I was preſent at it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You ſurprize me.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Will this ſatisfy you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
A witneſs may be ſuborned. The law
will ſcarcely be content with one perſon's teſtimony.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: With mine it clearly will.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You may be miſtaken, ſir. It will be raſh to riſk it. I will make an offer, a handſome offer—We will reſign our claim to half the fortune, manage the buſineſs with the ladies as you pleaſe, you may depend on our ſecreſy. We tender to you, mind, to yourſelf half the fortune.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: It is a handſome offer.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Very indeed! may be you think a third would be enough.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: No, no, far from it; for though the bribe ſounds handſomely, it would be want of policy in me to take it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: For this plain reaſon, that, tho' I admit theſe ladies to be Cleveland's wife and daughter, ſtill Cleveland's fortune is the right of—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You! by what title?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: The cleareſt in the world—founded on the ſimple principle, that while a man can prove himſelf alive, his heirs are not allowed to take poſſeſſion of his property.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Alive!

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Why, gentlemen, you are very hard to be convinced. Surely you ſhould admit a man alive, when he is able himſelf to tell you ſo.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear!

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: And, how do you now feel yourſelves, my very worthy couſins? (Goes to the door.) Come, come in, and thank your kinſmen for all their kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: Oh, Leonard, Leonard, did I ever think you would have brought me into ſuch diſgrace!

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Senſible rebuke of age to youth! You ſhould have led your ſon into the path of honeſty, not been ſeduced by him into the road of villainy.

sp.speaker: Old Viſ.
sp.p: I'll go home, and if I continue in my preſent mind, I think it very likely I ſhall hang myſelf before to-morrow morning. Oh Leonard, Leonard! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: With your company, ſir, (to Leonard.) I cannot diſpenſe, till I receive aſſurance that my property remitted to you is veſted as I directed.

div.stage: Enter DROOPLY, CAROLINE, HENRY, and OAKWORTH.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: My worthy brother, give me joy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Your brother!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Even ſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You are well paired. I wiſh you all the happineſs that mutual poverty can give you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Poverty! nay, we need not ſtarve. My eſtate is ſurely ſufficient to prevent that.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Your eſtate! You muſt firſt perſuade me to reſign the writings of it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thank you, dear brother; but you happen to forget you have already done that.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I! how—when?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: By your direction I brought the box to town with me, which you ſaid, contained the writings.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes,—ay—that box—hey! let me ſee it—I have got the key of it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p:
The key, my dear fellow! Do you think
I do things ſo curſed mechanically as to want keys? A man juſt come into poſſeſſion of an eſtate, and not break open the box that contained his claim to it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What, broke open!

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes, with a kitchen poker. Lord, how alarmed you are! Yes, I broke it open, and found I had killed two birds with one ſtone; for, inſtead of only getting the writings of one eſtate, I found the writings of two—This lady's and my own.

div.stage: A perſon enters and converſes apart with CLEVELAND, and then Exit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Curſes fall on me!

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: That they will, faſt enough never fear. What a ſhrewd gueſſer you muſt be! You had the wiſdom to foreſee, that ſome time or other, there would be a junction of the properties, and you therefore commodiouſly packed up the writings together. Ah, you are a conſiderate fellow!

sp.speaker: Clev. to Leonard.
sp.p: Sir, we need your preſence here no longer. My property I find is veſted as I appointed. Now, ſir, depart, loaded not with my reproaches, not with my malediction; for the whole world's contempt, and the heavieſt curſes of the injured would add but a feather's weight to the mountain of remorſe which conſcious guilt will heap upon thy wretched boſom. When I reflect on the ſeverity of ſuffering conſcience can inflict, I could almoſt forget my injuries, and pity thee.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
To palliate my guilt I do not ſeek—yet, in juſtice, let me declare, the erroneous judgment of the world made me a villian. I beheld the eye of obſervance and reſpect ever directed to the wealthy; were he fool or knave, no matter.
While all that is truly amiable or great in genius or in virtue, when linked with poverty, was heeded with the ſtare of diſavowal, or the ſcowl of contempt. To be a golden idol for the world's worſhip was my aim. I have loſt my fortune, character, and happineſs in the attempt, and now muſt meet in penury mankind's abhorrence, and feel too, I deſerve it. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: (to Caroline.) I grieve to think how much you muſt be afflicted.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am indeed; for with all his unworthineſs, I cannot forget he is my brother.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Such remembrance honours you; for never ſhould the principles of juſtice abſorb the feelings of nature.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Ah, my good friend, you at liberty!

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I found bail.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: I am very glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Mrs Clev.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall ever feel myſelf your debtor.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh, Madam!

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: I know a way to repay him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: By making him rightful poſſeſſor of the treaſure he holds in his hand.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Gangica, do you conſent to—

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.p: I do all as you pleaſe, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I am ſure it will pleaſe me that you make yourſelf happy.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Now I have performed my promiſe, you muſt renew my acquaintance with your father.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: You and my father, ſir, have never been aſunder.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Hey! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: To reſtore you a truant ſon, ſir, who, till he had atoned as far as lay in his power for his former errors, could not hope to be acknowledged by ſuch a father.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: What, my own boy turned out an honeſt man?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; and who, now knowing the precious value of that firſt of titles, will never forfeit it.

sp.speaker: Oakw.
sp.p: Now, then, I can ſay I am completely happy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clev.
sp.p: Ever, ever may you remain ſo!—You will; for benevolence like yours makes the human heart a heaven.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: The gratitude I owe to all who have befriended theſe dear objects of my love, I hope to ſhew by ſomething more than words. What a proſpect of happineſs opens to our view! Bleſt with friends, proved ſuch in the trying moments of affliction—with fortune to command profuſely every luxury, and I truſt, with minds to employ it only in purſuit of one—the luxury of doing good.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.byline: WRITTEN BY JOHN TAYLOR, ESQ. AND SPOKEN BY MRS. POPE.

lg.l: WELL, tho' our Bard has try'd his utmoſt art
To ſhew how riches will pollute the heart,
No doubt his labour has been all in vain,
And poverty will ne'er one convert gain.
How could the man attempt a taſk ſo bold!
But what, forſooth, can authors know of gold?
An ore that rarely darts on them a beam,
Unleſs, perchance, in hope's deluſive dream;
Hope, that miſleads them thro' life's weary way,
And ſcarcely leaves at laſt the barren bay.
What, wean the human heart from love of pelf!
A toil, too hard for Hercules himſelf!
Nay, that great hero, as we learn in ſtory,
Strove for a little gain, as well as glory,
Elſe why attack the dreadful ſcaly brute,
If not to graſp the rich Heſperian fruit?
Hence, av'rice is a paſſion not ſo odd,
Since, as we find, it urg'd a demi-god.
'Twas alſo ſaid of yore the female tribe,
Are frail as men when tempted by a bribe,
And mighty Jove, with all his boaſted pow'r
Was forc'd to woo amid a golden ſhow'r.
Oh! wond'rous charm of all-perſuaſive gold,
That fires the timid, and ſubdues the bold.
Gold, that can give the upſtart blockhead fame,
And make a fawning world his wit proclaim;
That lends deformity reſiſtleſs grace,
O'erthrows the mighty, and exalts the baſe;
Great ſubſtitute for learning, genius, worth,
Deſpotic ſovereign of adoring earth!
But let me check the raſh injurious thought,
For, in this court, no verdict can be bought.
Here merit ſafely may aſſert her plea,
While candour regulates the mild decree;
And by that candour one who oft has try'd
Its gen'rous force, his fate muſt now abide,
In hopes one error more will pardon find,
Since to his others you've ſo long been kind.

div.head: NEW PUBLICATIONS PRINTED FOR T. N. LONGMAN and O. REES, No. 39, Paternoſter-Row.
div.p: 1. THE LIFE of CATHARINE II. EMPRESS of RUSSIA. The Third Edition, with conſiderable Improvements. In Three Volumes, 8vo. Price 1l. 4s. in Boards. Embelliſhed with Seven elegant Portraits, and a correct Map of Ruſſia.

To the concurrent teſtimonies of all the periodical publications of taſte and literature already adduced, we ſhall only add, from the European Magazine, that the writer of their Review, after delaying his account of the Work, in order to aſcertain its authenticity, in the number for November laſt, ſays: "On the moſt indiſputable teſtimony, and the higheſt authority, the writer has it now in his power to declare that theſe volumes, under the modeſt and limited title of The Life of the late Empreſs of Ruſſia, compriſe a faithful and impartial Hiſtory of the Political Tranſactions and Publick Affairs of the Northern Courts of Europe during the Reign of Catharine II.; together with a regular narration of the progreſſive aggrandiſement, civilization, and general improvement, of the Ruſſian Empire, from the time of Peter the Great to that of the Death of the late Empreſs in 1796."
2. ANECDOTES of LORD CHATHAM's LIFE. The Sixth Edition. In Three Volumes, 8vo. Price 18s. Boards.
div.q: The author has made a valuable collection of Anecdotes, eſpecially of the late and moſt conſpicuous part of Lord Chatham's Life; and of other matters connected with it. He ſays he is not conſcious of having advanced one falſehood: we give credit to his declacation, having found no cauſe to doubt it. Monthly Review, May 1792.

q.p: A greater number of curious and intereſting Anecdotes, concerning public affairs, have not appeared ſince the days of Sir William Temple, than are to be met with in this work.
We cannot diſmiſs this article without acknowledging, that it throws a great and new light upon the occurrences and events of more than half a century of our hiſtory.

BIOGRAPHICAL, LITERARY, and POLITICAL ANECDOTES, of ſeveral of the moſt EMINENT PERSONS of the PRESENT AGE; particularly the Dukes of Grafton, Leeds, Dorſet, and Rutland; Lords Townſhend, Orford, Marchmont, Mansfield, Camden, Temple, Nugent, and Sackville; Biſhops of Hereford and Oſſory; Right Hon. George Grenville, Charles Townſhend; Sir James Caldwell, Sir Grey Cooper, Sir John Dalrymple, Serjeant Adair, Dr. Franklin, and many others; never before printed. In Three Volumes. Price 18s.
